text: I was just there and spent a couple minutes at the counter waiting to order but the people working there didn't even bother to look at me while they were talking amongst themselves. It's a really small place. I made a comment and they snapped back telling me to wait.  I left and am not ever going back.
Terrible.  Had a pork bone in my lechon sandwich.  Awesome to bite into it.  Stay away....

I'm a frequent visitor to all locations, but I was hugely disappointed by this location... We were waiting 45 minutes for our 3 orders- while 3 other customers received their food even though they ordered after us. My initial order was not complete and after I came all the way back to work we open our meals only to see THEY ARE WRONG!!! When I called , I got offered a store credit?!  Are you kidding me...? I work in customer service as well and I get it gets busy- but I'm just not supposed to eat now because you can only offer store credit? Whomever is managing this location should really think about having more staff to help because it's very clear your cashier and cooks are overwhelmed... I will go to their Armitage location only ..

I live around the area and its my second time ordering from the daily special. I went in and ordered the steak sandwich with no onions. I dont try to be difficult but in my pictures you will see they did this on purpose. The sandwich looked amazing and the yuca fries smothered in the chimichurri sauce. They kid still came out and saked if i wanted it to go or to eat in. I had already told him i wanted to eat in the place. Talk about service. Im in the industry and seriously hope business owners teach your staff customer service. The cook was talking smack in front of me and the girl that works there told him that i was right there. To stop lol. This is ridiculous. I wanted to send it back but maybe the second time i bet they wouldve all spat on my food. So not coming back. I ate my meal because i payed for it and was hungry. These people should feel ashamed of themselves.
Pretty good sandwiches. I had the cubano my wife had the ropa vieja. Yummy plantain chips. Side salad was $6 and probably cost them .25 to make. Skip that.

This is a top-notch Cuban restaurant if you're looking for a real Cuban experience to go along with the food come here. It may be a bit small but once you walk in you feel like you're in Cuba without a doubt. Service is awesome which i love and the pastries were a definite plus highly recommend!!!!!

Dined here with my mother and had the most extraordinary Cubano to date :) This 90 Miles packed a whole lot of flavor and care into a unique space and we Loved it!  The restaurant is too small to accommodate inside tables or stools and this very reason allows for communal dining - lively Cuban music greeted us and within minutes, our food was ready!  We sat on the patio outside, took our time with eating and left happy :) We shared the crispy Mariquitas with mojo de ajo and the mixture of chiles, garlic, and olive oil drizzled on the thin plantain chips had me drooling for more. My mom had to stop me from getting an extra order to go. Splitting a Cubano for a snack was a great idea because it's a nice sized sandwich, but  after my first bite I kinda wanted to eat it all myself....if I wasn't with my mom, I probably would've--I'm just sayin'  The Cubano had deliciously soft and crispy bread, juicy ham and roasted pork, salty Swiss cheese, tangy mustard, and fresh pickles. I'm craving one right now. The layers were perfectly proportioned and I savored every bite. I was disappointed in the congrí:  when I sent back my cold rice, it seems to have just been microwaved instead of replaced - due to the shape of the rice staying the same and just coming back steamed. The Arroz Amarillo, on the other hand, came out hot and fluffy, full of savory spices, and made me want to take it to bed...to finish eating while watching a romantic comedy.  I will visit the other locations just to get Arroz Amarillo and a Cubano.  You know, to, uh, check quality control. Right? Right. Yum :)
Good food, yummy sandwiches, empanadas.  Service friendly. Food slow to come out. Nice outdoor seating but beware, no shade.

Visited this place when I was in Chicago and I saw it on triple D.  I took the train and it was a about 2 blocks away.  So pretty easy to get to.  I ordered the Cuban sandwich and it was OK, didn't think it was anything special.  Th atmosphere is pretty cool and it has a decent crowd.  I would visit again to try some of the other dishes.

Looks like great food. I wouldn't know. Went in for a Cubano on a Monday for their special and they were sold out by 12:30pm. Not really all that special if they can't keep it running all day. Should prep better for service. EDIT: Robert did reach out after this review to offer me a Cubano at their Armitage location. Good customer service, but it's like mcdonalds saying they have no French fries! Or having a happy hour special and running out of all the food!
It's good but I had better The white rice was a little cold that's the only thing I did not like otherwise everything else was a thumbs up
Well worth going out of your way for. Authentic cooking, fun atmosphere, top notch service. I would drive OVER 90 miles to enjoy their cuisine. ;-)
Oh, this place is so great! Such delicious food! It's a low key restaurant, but worth the wait! Saturday night: packed to the top. Our server Marcos was fabulous:) Def. coming back soon.

The Cuban sandwich here is bad. It has tough, cheap sliced pork filled with inedible chunks of grizzle. I was literally spitting it out onto my plate as I worked through the sandwich. Service was friendly but extremely slow. I live near here and likely won't be back.

This is the original location for the 90 Miles Cuban restaurant chain. You can get some great authentic Cuban food here. Went here recently and had the Guajiriti which is a pounded steak with Romaine lettuce, tomato, onions, swiss cheese and chimichurri in a green plantain sandwich. Also had the pan con lechon which is roasted pork Citrus mango, grilled onions with fried sweet plantains in a special sauce.  Served on either a white or wheat French baguette with plantain chips or french fries. My favorite so far is the pan con lechon sandwich. This location has a small indoor eating area with a larger Outdoors patio area which is a great place to be on a nice warm sunny day. Prices can't be beat and as you can see by my pictures the portions are large and very filling. The employees were cordial and helpful.  All in all it's a great place to grab a sandwich or even check out the specials cuz they have some wonderful deals.
Very good grab and go Cuban style food. The yuca fries are not to miss. The garlic sauce that come with them hits all the right notes.

Love this gem by my house! Always kind people working, and the food is great. Reminds me of living in Miami each time I enter with the upbeat Cuban music playing. They have a nice patio to sit outside too when the weather is good. Great cafe con leches!
The empanadas are great . But I have to give them 3 stars because when I order for take out they gave me the bag with one entree missing .

I usually wouldn't give 90 Miles only 2 stars. I love the food and it's very tasty, however, I'm disappointed that my dish was very disappointing this time. For a $16 dish I would have expected more than just 5 small cubes of tofu and a not so generous amount of vegetables. There was also more soup than black beans in the container. We carried out and waited a long time for our food as others that came in after us were getting theirs. I hope that this experience was just a one-time fluke. I don't know if carry-out from this location is a good option anymore.
Great vibe with really good authentic Cuban food. Very simplistic decor but it works. Service is excellent. You feel at home.

What a horrible experience this was today.  Our first  time eating here not knowing it wasn't table, sit down style. Anyhow, my husband asked the guy with the rimmed hat at the cash register if they had Ropa Vieja he said yes but it only comes with plantain chips. My husband asked if we could get something else even for an up charge. The guy said no, it'd be full charge for a side. While waiting for our food we noticed people to the side of us ordered the same with fries. It was an up charge not to mention the special of the day included a choice of fries or yucca and a drink. Knowing it was our first time there he should have mentioned the special. When my husband received his order there was hardly any meat inside the bread, literally the Ropa didn't cover the bread. He asked the guy if this is standard and if he could get a bit more what he paid for.  The counter guy copped a huge attitude grabbed the plate put way too much on and rudely handed it back with his attitude.  I've worked most of my life in the food industry and you don't do that. The guy absolutely made the experience suck.  Definitely won't be going back....

Like Cuban food? You won't be blown away here, but you also won't be disappointed. Definitely a B+, solid spot for Cuban fare in my book. The menu has everything you need and nothing you don't. And for gluten-free folks like myself, it's fairly easy to eat here. I highly recommend the guajirito sandwich (similar to a jibarito), which is a dreamy combination of steak, crisp romaine lettuce, tomato, grilled onions, Swiss cheese and chimichurri sauce - all served between two grilled plantains. It's garlicky goodness, my friends! And you won't even miss the bread - I wish I could eat everything on top of grilled plantains, honestly. The café is pretty tiny, but they have have a few patio tables outside. Just a note that the patio is no longer dog-friendly!
Over priced food. Twice I've eaten here some sandwiches and have become sick. It's too greasy. Will not be returning.

Bottom line:  I love the food at 90 Miles' Armitage location in Bucktown/Logan, but if I can get the same food for four dollars less per sandwich at the Clybourn location, I'm going to do that ten times out of ten.  Goodbye Armitage, hello Clybourn!  (The free parking, fast service and daily specials don't hurt either.)

I was directed over to this little gem while waiting on my dog's treatment nearby at the veterinary center. It's a terrific spot for a quick snack or a full meal. I had their chicken soup (delightful) and a couple of their beef and potato croquettes (quite filling). It's a tiny spot but the staff is friendly and prices reasonable. I'm eager to try some of their other offerings.

First time trying too small and cozy restaurant in Lakeview. I ordered the Pollo de fricassee, which is another name for Pollo guisado or stew chicken. It was served in a nice steel pot alongside white rice black beans and 3 sweet plantains. Very good portion for $17, which was a little bit more than I wanted to pay but the food was well worth it. Sitting is limited to sitting against the wall on  bar stools and it is counter service which is fine by me. There were a lot of great things there but I didn't want to spend too much money, and perhaps next time I'll try some of their other attractive-looking items on the menu. All in all highly recommend anyone to try this wonderful restaurant..

Great place- lots of options! For an appetizer, we got something that was incredible but I can't remember what it was called.  As my entree, I ordered the Lechon (roasted pork, citrus mojo, house seasoning, grilled onions ) My friend got the Bistec Empanisado sandwich (steak, romaine, tomato, chimichurri, grilled onion, shoe-string potatoes)

So I decided to spend my holiday season getting Cuban food from the most popular place in Chicago. I spent $70 and got food Togo. All my food was ruined and they didn't even probably pack my food and it all leaked all over the car and everywhere else. This was a complete was of money thanks for wasting good food with your lazy service, learn how to pack food you lazy people!

9:55am on a Thursday, door was locked. Just called to see if they were open. Woman answered the phone with food in her mouth. Laughed and put me on hold.  When I asked if they were open, she laughed and said, "like yes, I have customers" and laughed. I asked if she can unlock the door., Without checking, she stated quite rudely, "it is open!" It clearly wasn't as I was pushing and pulling on their glass entrance door that wouldn't open. Bye bye. She didn't even try to be polite. On our way to Señor pan as I type. So much more down to earth there.
This place is amazing. The Spanish music, the art all over the walls, the food, the sun coming through the window, the service, the Cuban coffee...just go there. You won't be disappointed.
I love this place. The food is amazing and the owner is very nice. Everything I have had from here was nothing short of mouth watering.

Really enjoyed this place. After seeing it on the food network show "Diners, Drive-ins, and Dives". Checked this one off the list of must places to go.  I ordered the Fricase de pollo served with rice, beans and maduros. All I can is it was amazing, and priced well.

Solid Cuban food, fresh ingredients, delicious flavors, lowkey location. It's kind of a bummer that they don't have a large seating area inside but taking advantage of their outdoor patio seating during warm months is great. Parking is a non-issue because it's not located in a high traffic area, so it's convenient for pick ups. I've never had anything here that wasn't good, try it!
great cuban sandwiches at this tiny gem. both locations are good but i prefer the original. I'm a fan of the classic Cubano but everything I've had is tasty.

I've eaten at 90 miles quite a few times and had great experiences, but tonight we ordered in from them via Door Dash and the food was less than great.  1. One of the dishes had spilled all over the delivery bag, making unpacking a huge mess 2. The black beans tasted canned -- no bueno 3. No dressing with our salad 4. The veggie dish was supposed to be mushroom based and there was not a single mushroom to be seen Regretful $50 spent.

A unique experience for Chicago dining. The cafe is tremendously decorated with prints of old newspapers and painted scenes.  Inside the cafe is where you order your food at the cashier. Then there is a small outdoor patio with hanging lights and tables, where they bring out your food.  I enjoyed an avocado omelet in French bread which was absolutely delicious and my fellow diner enjoyed a burger.  It's BYOB and very reasonably priced.

Just left 90 miles. Although usually a fantastic experience this time is the second bad experience. Today the croquetas were over fried, the Cuban sandwich was dry and the park was fatty and dry. I am convinced the owners haven't been there in a while. The staff was nice but the food was not the same.
The food is great, feels like authentic cuban. If you have the chance, try eating it outside!

We had to wait 30 minutes for our food. It wasn't that busy at 5:00 pm. Then I can hear the employees arguing because the cook has been over worked and was scheduled to leave at a certain time and the new guy has been on the job for only 3 days and needs training. The owner was not present to see this drama!! Food was average.

PLEASE look at my pictures and tell me if that looks appetizing. I ordered the Guajirito sandwich. I have had these before so I knew what to expect, but what I got was sickening. It looked and tasted disgusting. First, they brought it over and the first thing I noticed was the sandwich sitting in a pool of oil. At that moment I lost my appetite but because my boss took me to lunch, I felt obligated to eat a few bites so as not to make him feel bad. I picked up half the sandwich and the oil dropped off steadily, the plantains  AND steak were completely soaked in oil. I took my first bite and knew right away they did not fry the plantain long enough. It was limp and somewhat "chewy", you know, the texture of a plantain that is still half raw? It was nasty. Listen, I know the plantains are fried and I'm ok with that but they shouldn't be dripping oil and they should definitely be fried to the point of slight crispness on the outside. The steak should not be dripping oil. They should be embarrassed that they served this to a customer. The rice was ok. Not fabulous, but edible. It was my first time there and it will be my last. I know that this is not what the sandwich should look and taste like, as I've had them before and they've been delicious. Big disappointment.

I drive regularly from glenview to city to eat. Always place order before arriving but this place did not answer there phone for 1 hour 30 minutes! Drove all the way there for them to tell me 45 to close that they are done not taking any orders?!? Why couldn't u answer ur phone the 100 times I called. Very rude staff and customer service

This place is located on an odd corner, but there is a parking lot at the side. It is very, very small and carryout only in the winter. The prices are very fair for the amount of food you get as well.  I got the Ropa Vieja sandwich which was really good. The bread was warm and soft, and the meat was very tender and flavorful. Lots of juice as well, yum. The portion was good for the price especially. I really enjoyed it. As a side I got the Yuca fries which were BOMB. They were crispy and starchy, so delicious. They came with a pepper oil which was alright, but not super flavorful. I enjoyed the fries by themselves more. My friend got the Media Noche which she said was very filling and delicious, she also got fried plantains which were kind of soggy and not as good as the Yuca fries I had. Overall a positive experience, and I'd definitely go back again!  I would give this 5 stars, but a friend was comparing it to a different Cuban join, and I had to agree that a lot of food there was a little tastier.
A dive! Great Cuban sandwiches and empanadas. Super friendly staff. Cute but small inside. Nice outdoor seating. Not a great area of town but the best dives are usually in these types of places.

Just found out about this place and have been a few times already. I have tried different sandwiches each time and they have all been great. The Yuca fries are delicious too.  My only complaint which is the parking sucks. Not only is it small but everyone seems to make their own spot which blocks everyone in. I think having it paved and painted with lines would help somewhat.
The food and service are always great here at 90 miles. Unfortunately this time with the passing of my grandmother I won't be able to bring her the great food I use to bring her from 90miles.

When I was ordering, the young man with glasses taking my order gave me attitude for asking what the difference was between the $7 and $8 option for the chicken sandwich. When he served me, he didn't give me or the African and Latino gentleman sitting across from me any napkins after we politely asked. But when there were Caucasian people, he gave them sauce, napkins, and a lick in the ass. There was barely any chicken in the sandwich and I was given scraps for plantains. Before I left, I decided to do this guy a favor and hand him my plate myself. He gave me a smirk and responded with a disrespectful "thanks bro". I mean with 6 customers he's going to need all the help he can get.

OMG! Just called to place a take out order and was told that they didn't offer the menu they have posted online. I asked what menu I should order off of and was told the one online but that they don't have everything on it. I asked what other items were excluded so I could review and make a new selection and call back and the guy hung up on me. So, I called back and explained that I was hung up on and wondered how they wanted me to place my order. To which he replied "I don't have time to go through this with you" and hung up on me again. WTF?!?!??! I laughed out loud. That is the most absurd service I have ever been given. Literally. I'm a nice, normal person trying to patron your business and you hang up on me not once but twice?! I truly wasn't being a jerk on the phone but apparently this place has so much business that they don't need any more so I am very happy to go elsewhere... it's Chicago and there are hundreds of amazing places (and don't worry 90 miles... with service like this, you will burn out and the next new thing will come sweeping in faster than you know it).
It s a hole in the wall but the food was surprisingly good and the service was fast!  Don't miss out:)
pick a sunny day, get the Mariquitas for app, and then get the Churrasco for your main! Best Cuban around town!! The service was fantastic, really nice people working here!
Very good Cubano sandwich and Cafe Cubano. Very fairly priced for Chicago (7 bones for the sandwich and 1 for the coffee) - I plan to visit again when I'm in the area.

One of the most overpriced sandwiches for what you get that I've had in a while (next to Panera Bread). Mostly bread and very little meat; typical for most places serving sandwiches these days. Also, the side of beans was laughable! See pic... perhaps the entrées are better but will most likely never find out I don't intend to return.

Best Cuban food in Chicago! The pork is amazing.  Everything on the menu is so good.  Empanadas are excellent.   Great place for coffee as well.   Many mornings I'll go by there and get their coffee and hit the road.
Best Cuban food ever.  Fast service, good quality.  I come here once a week or more.
Just love this place.  They have the best attitude and food is fresh.  That said with spinach and avocado was perfect, just the right amount of balsamic vinegar.  Perfection.

I love Cuban food and 90 miles does not disappoint! I went there for the second time this weekend and it has to be one of my favorite spots. The empanadas are a must! The beef is my favorite but you can't go wrong with the chicken or mozzarella. We tried the chorizo/goat cheese but the goat cheese was just too overpowering. The empanadas have a perfectly flakey crust with gooey centers. Also try the snickers version for dessert. The churrasco is hands down my favorite entree. You get a huge serving of skirt steak and the flavor is incredible. I had my first yuca cob mojo here and it's delicious. Similar to potatoes but velvetier. I wanted to try something else but couldn't bring myself to pass this up. I sampled some of my friends fricase de pollo and croqueta which were both delicious but would still choose the steak =) Pros: The food- seriously everything is fantastic! BYOB- you can literally bring a bottle of whatever with no cork fee.. rum, wine, beer (think of the $$$ you save) Con: Busy- Make a reservation in advance especially the weekends

Stopped here for a quick bite.  The quirky wall paper reminded me of the Cuba -US historical relationship, but transported me to an earlier time.  The space may feel like a hole-in-the-wall, but the flavors make up for what is lacks in space.  I had the Ropa Vieja ( shredded beef) sandwich and was in heaven!  Authentic flavors, not pretentious, humble but surprising!  I'll be back!

We went to the Clybourn location. Holy cow. If I could give them an extra half star, I would. I come from Miami and spent most of my life eating this type of food. It's the closest taste to home I have tried in Chicago.

Im not sure if this location(clybourn ave) has the same owners as the others but out of the three I find this one to be the least friendly (at least when there is a young woman with blondish hair serving the counter) and the one that over salts their food the most. If that wasnt enough, the ropa vieja sandwich ordered had a measly amount of meat..(im talking less than the size of my fist and Im a small girl so my fist is pretty small) and it was a sandwich yet we got the meat and bread seperate..didn't know it was a create your own sandwhich kind of deal.  My bistec sandwich was super greasy. I had to blot it with a napkin and it soaked up the entire napkin. Now we all know we dont eat Cuban food for their health benefits but still I also dont expect a greasy spoon type order.. The only good thing from our visit was their cafe con leche.  If you have dined at their other locations, dont come here expecting the same quality or like me..you'll be in for a dissapointment. Oh yes and when I brought it to their attention, made no effort to rectify the situation.

This place never disappoints. As a proud Puerto Rican, I lay claim to having the best tostones, but I have to ignore the crispy, tender, salty snacks at 90 Miles. No matter, Cubans can fry a plantain like the best of us. From the media noche to the bistec de palomilla, everything is seasoned to my liking and fresh. Cafe con leche is on point with flavor, even though I could do with less sugar sometimes.  This location is counter service with some sweet and savory empanadas to carry out. Either check out the daily lunch sandwich specials above the water jug (available until 5pm) or ask for a full menu. At all hours I've found the cashier to be willing to make recommendations. Grab one of the few stools inside and the cashier will bring your dinner to you. If you don't order a drink they have plastic cups and a water jug for you to help yourself. It can get really crowded during colder months since there are so few seats in this corner lot space. They offer delivery and carryout if you'd prefer to eat at home. Heck, you could even sit in your car in their lot if you didn't want to wait. I wouldn't judge. Before you go: I recommend the masitas de puerco appetizer. It's magically crispy on the outside and super tender and juicy inside. Plus, fried pork.

Loved this place. Until they forgot to put my chips in my bag I politely called back and told them they forgot it the woman responded saying she didn't charge me for them which was a lie cuz I had the receipt. Make sure you check your bag before you leave because this is not the first time it's happened to me. Won't be eating here again. They one on armitage is way nicer better food and definitely better service
Great sandwiches and traditional Cuban dishes. Love the island feel and the friendly service...

I am a single middle-aged woman who often dines alone. I tried twice (January 22nd and 29th )  to have dinner At 90 Miles, and both times I went in I was ignored and not seated. I waited 12 minutes the first time and 9 minutes the second, both around 730 pm. I'll have to go down the street to Sabor  de Cuba and eat earlier for my Cuban food fix. Can't rate the food; only the service.

90 mile is decent place. But it small portions and it's mad expensive. Plus it's packed like all the time cause hipsters love byob. I've dropped this place off my radar and started to search for that perfect Cuban joint. It's a great place of people who charge things on their credit card then report them stolen the next day. I think the proper name for those people are "scumbags". But for us common folk. No point on dropping that much coin on rice & plantains.

(Update: this is for the logan square location) I went on a Friday with my boyfriend for dinner. We didn't have a reservation but we're able to find parking and be seated right away even though it was crowded.  Atmosphere is great if you want a good time for a group of friends because it is loud - so not a good place for a quiet conversation. It's also BYOB which is nice. We brought a bottle of rum and got the moijito pitcher. Probably not the best moijito only because I don't consider myself a bartender so maybe the portions were off, but still very tasty. For an appetizer we got empanadas which you order in 3s. We ordered spinach, chicken, and chorizo/goat cheese. All were delicious and a good amount of filling with a flaky pastry crust that tastes homemade.  For an entree we got bistec de palomilla which comes with white rice and beans and cooked plaintains, a typical cuban dinner. The steak was thin cut and flavorful but I would probably get something different next time because it had too many onions for my liking which overpowered the steak. Overall, it was a pleasant experience and our waitress was very nice and friendly. I would like to try it again during the summer when there is outdoor seating available.
excellent cuban sandwhiches.  bread is particularly good.   warning: not fast.  expect to wait 10-15 minutes for anything you order

I am in LOVE with 90 Miles Cuban Cafe! I had no idea I'd find a vegan-friendly Cuban place and this was certainly a surprise.  The tofu dish--made with tofu, pepper, and onion simmered in creole sauce and white wine--was to die for!  It was obvious that time and care was put into the preparation of this food because it was just phenomenal. This is also a great place for vegans and non-vegans to dine together as there are options for everyone.  My boyfriend loved the meat dish he ordered too.

Great little Cuban eat in. Very authentic Cubano sandwiches. Cannot beat this place. Sandwiches are filled with meat. The lechon is great. Very tender and moist. Empanadas are also amazing. Very fresh! Easy 5 stars.

The empanadas and sandwiches, especially  La Media Noche, are fantastic! Super autentico and made with love. I didn't know it was BYOB my first time there, but the drinks are great with or without a mixer! While it's a small joint, it is super cute with a great atmosphere.  Great food for the price - you're paying the same amount or more for e.coli at chipotle, or some fries at a red robin, so why not try 90 Miles, a casual place with FLAVORFUL food.

The place is small but the food is huge with flavor!  I ordered the Cubano sandwich and beef empanadas.   The sandwich was fresh with just the right amount of mustard to pickle ratio which complimented the meats perfectly.  The bread was fresh and toasted just right. The empanadas were amazing!  Perfectly crunchy on the outside and full of complex savory favors inside. The staff was busy but very cordial.  Always a smile and willing to answer a question.  I will be back!

My boyfriend and I went there last night for the first time because it was recommended and I must say the food was DELICIOUS! We split the Cubano and the Bistec De Palomilla and ordered 3 empanadas (mozzarella, spinach & beef). The empanadas were served with a chimichurri sauce and some homemade sauce which was outstanding. There isn't a lot of room to eat inside but we managed and Luis the manager, couldn't have been any friendlier! Everything we had tasted delicious and can't wait to go there again and try their breakfast! If you haven't tried this place, you must go!

This place is awesome! I order a sandwich from here about once a week and it's always good. Ive tried several things on the menu including the coffee and have yet to be disappointed. I will continue to recommend 90 miles to everyone I know.

Small space with great character. Outside dog friendly seating (w/ heaters). Others also picking up call-in orders. Lydia super helpful guiding us first-timers through the menu. Definitely will return.
An explosion of flavor in my mouth! Loved the guajerito sandwich. My boyfriend had the cubano and we shared congri. We both enjoyed the food and will definitely be coming back for more.

Yummmm! BYOB. The empanadas (chorizo and goat cheese) are awesome! My husband and I typically order three empanadas and split an entrée. Rips Vieja is our favorite. Recommend for dine in during summer, great outdoor seating but carry out during winter

Have to say the new place looks beautiful, but I think perhaps I was there on an "off" day as I was unimpressed with the food, I ordered 3 Cuban's, 1"Medianoche"and a "Gillbabirrto" they all came with banana chips (which happened to be my favorite) but the chips were to soggy to eat, the Cubans had mayonnaise on them ( which doesn't apply to an Original Cuban ) and they weren't on Cuban Bread. Now, I recognize the fact that I'm picky but what can I say, I know what I like.
Holy grease ball batman. Super disappointed in this sandwich. The bread was soaked everything.
This is one of my favorite finds on the North side. The restaurant is small, with only enough seats for a handful of people. Don't let that scare you away because the food is amazing.
Food was pretty good but some of the items are very very oily. The sandwiches are pretty good! I probably wouldn't go out of my way but if I'm in the area, it would be an option.
Really nice place, nice service, tasty tostones and yuca frita. So so on the pork.  Needs a little more flavor. But overall good.

Ordered takeout. Food was ready quickly, the cashier was friendly, and everything we got was tasty. Shrimp empanadas were soft and flavorful, while the ropa vieja both in sandwich and entree form was juicy and really hit the spot.

This is a fabulous little spot serving the best Cuban fare around.  It's an interesting concept that fits very well into this establishment's name, 90 Miles Cuban Cafe. The lechon I had was excellent as was the Cuban sandwich on another visit. It was equally as good.  The French fries and fried plantain chips are great too!   This place can be hoping....... Improve your customer service!   ... Looks like  you have plenty of help, step out from the back counter and be a tad more accomodating to your patrons.  Maybe some colorful tablecloths outside in summer would surely draw attention and bring more people in.   Action and people bring more people! On the two occasions I was there, the food was fantastic but it was dead.  Do something positive to bring more people in. Walk outside and ask people how's it going.  Refill their drinks but step out from behind the counter.  You're not White Castle's, you have to work harder! I ll be back ... I want you to earn that 5th star!
Great hole in the wall with excellent food! This is my old neighborhood, so I'm a little biased. Friendly people, good service, fair prices. Haven't had food Cuban steak since I lived in Miami.

AWESOME Cuban food!! I was inspired to go here after watching the movie Chef (great movie btw!). This restaurant did not disappoint. The atmosphere was low key and very nice. I loved the patio seating. I had the croqueta sandwich and the bread pudding. The sandwich was melty and delightful! The bread pudding was like no bread pudding I have ever had.. but in a good way! The texture was more like flan than bread pudding. My boyfriend who dislikes bread pudding and flan helped me finish the entire thing! I highly recommend 90 Miles to Cuba. The staff is friendly and the food is great :)
Solid food and fun scene. Long wait but a good place to go with friends for drinks and dinner. Had my birthday celebration there and all enjoyed.

Best Cuban I've ever had in my life! Better than any Cuban place I could find in Miami so that's really saying something. So do your taste buds a favor and take yourself here!! Try the coffee and Plantine Sandwhich absolute musts

This place is super popular but it's really not THAT great. After going to the Roscoe Village location 5 times now, I realized that this place is merely popular with white people who have no idea what Cuban or Puerto Rican food is supposed to taste like . I am Puerto Rican and I lived on my island for 9 yrs. The two main ingredients in ALL the food is Sazon and Sofrito. Which this place uses neither. Its truly unbelievable to me that you can make this Caribbean food without these 2 critical ingredients which differentiate this food from any other country! Their empanadas are bland. In fact, all the food there has a blandness to it because of the lack of these two critical seasonings. The food is "pretty good" but OMG it  could.be  over the top delicious if they actually used the seasonings of Cuba and Puerto Rico!     Today, I got the papaya shake. They handed me a large glass of milk and sugar. Zero papaya fruit. They said it was in there but. You sure couldn't taste it. It was like a large glass of thick sweet creamer. Yuck.     In my opinion, If you're white and don't know any better you'll love this place. If you're from the Caribbean, there are tons better places.like Paladar in Logan Square!

This is the Original 90 Miles to Cuba @ 3101 N Clybourn Avenue (hint it's actually a little further then 90 miles to Cuba). It's a really cool tiny little restaurant on a triangular corner bordered by Elston, Oakley & Barry.  The decor both on the outside & inside are reminiscent of Cuban restaurants.  The dining inside is somewhat limited with NO tables & about 10 bar stools.  The walls on the inside are wallpapered with newspaper clippings from Cuban newspapers.  There is another newer & bigger "90 Miles to Cuba" @ 2540 W Armitage, but you need to experience the original one first.  I ordered the Cubano Sandwich it is delicious.  The perfect blend of ham, roasted pork, Swiss cheese, pickles & mustard toasted on a piece of toasted French bread & topped off with hot sauce.  If you like things spicy it's so much better w/the hot sauce.  This also comes with banana chips. I loved the food and the atmosphere of this restaurant and will be back to try some of the other items on the menu.  I also want to check out the other location on Armitage.
Hands down the best Cuban food in the city, blew me away.  The lechon is absolutely amazing.  Empanadas are awesome.  Overall amazing experience.
Amazing food and reasonable price!  Place is down the street from where I live/work and it always hits the spot!

I lived in South Florida for 12 years. I loved the Cuban cuisine and have missed it for almost 6 years.  I searched Chicago for a quality reviewed CUBAN (not Mexican) restaurant because I craved Masas de Puerco. This meal was phenomenal. The sweet plantains were so juicy and sweet. Two wedges of fresh lime for the fried pork chunks was the perfect amount to have a nice flavor of tropical lime.  I'm so pleased with my experience with this restaurant. I will be coming back.  Thank you for being so wonderful!!
Empanadas and plantains are fantastic!  Great meal for relatively inexpensive price.   Very friendly staff.  Quick service. Cute decor.  Definitely will return.

Great food at reasonable prices. The Cuban sandwiches and garlic sauce with the yuca fries are especially tasty. The guy who helped me was very patient and helpful as I labored over the menu trying to decide what I wanted. They don't seem to have any AC though so if its a hot day, be prepared to sweat as you wait for your order...let alone eating inside!

Really solid Cuban food that was super tasty without being greasy. The sweet plantains, Cuban sandwich and empanadas were all awesome. The tamale was good, a touch too sweet and didn't have much meat. A chicken dish was solid but a bit boring.  The price was a touch too high, so not a great value but if in the mood for Cuban and I'd definitely go back. An almost 2 hour wait for delivery on a Thursday is also a big detractor.
Loved the ropa vieja and empanadas. The outdoor patio is a great place to sit in the warmer months. Byob is an added bonus.

This location has all bar seats inside. On a nice day there are some tables on their patio. We ordered to go: We got the puerco rostizado...this was quite tender but didn't quite live up to our expectations....it lacked some flavor or kick. It was fine after adding a little hot sauce and salsa lizano The guave and cheese pastry was quite tasty. You can't go wrong.  The steak sandwich was pretty awesome with the onions and chimichurri sauce.  I'd probably try something different next time. it's very accessible and has a small parking by lot.

In response to the owner stating dogs must be outside the sidewalk cafe on a leash, I researched the claim and its unfounded.  According to the City Of Chicago Sidewalk Cafe rules and regulations section III Operation, subsection L states that "Dogs are allowed within the Sidewalk Cafe if it is accessible from the street." cityofchicago.org/conten…

the time it took to get my sammie was a little crazy-a cubano and it was 20 minutes until i had it in my hand togo? seems too long.  The sandwich was delicious though! I can't wait to try other sandwiches with more sauce.  I'll definitely be going back.

I've passed this cozy spot several times over the years, but only just recently got a chance to go into it. My mom sent me in for a cafe con leche, and I took this as an opportunity to scout the menu out, too. The decor is lovely, with old newspapers from Cuba and plenty of cultural art pieces. The space itself is small, but they do have an outdoor patio, which I imagine is nice for the summer.  The staff seemed overwhelmed by everything going on, and the restaurant wasn't even very busy. Maybe they were understaffed. The counter person was responsible for taking orders, running food and also making all the drinks, which depending on what you get, could take a while. There seemed to be confusion as to where food was going, which sort of dragged things out a while. I imagine it might help if the staff asked their customers if they would be seated indoors or on the patio.... I waited for 20+ minutes for two coffees and my shake. This was definitely more than I would like to wait, and I consider myself extremely patient. This time did give me the chance to look over the menu though, which was awkwardly placed next to the counter (making it hard for someone just walking in to really get to the menu BEFORE having to place the order). The food I did see looked delicious and reasonably priced. I would come back and try the food, but choose a time that's significantly less busy than a Saturday early afternoon....

This is a very small location which I think of mostly to go.... The sitting is very limited however the food is great!!! I've had the ropa vieja and the cubano sandwiches and they never disappoint me. I always get the cafe con leche here as well since they make it right then and there. Service could be a little bit friendlier but that doesn't stop me from coming back!! Lol Definitely recommend it to anyone in the area looking for a good Cuban sandwich!
Tried the Cuban sandwich and it was so bad. The pork and the ham had the consistency of jerky. No flavor. This place has no Cuban flavor. I pass.

I have spent a lot of time in Miami and I thought that was where I would find the best Cuban Sandwich. I was wrong!  90 Mile Cuban Cafe was outstanding. Service was equally impressive, the people were amazing. We were taking our dog to the Vet up the street and stopped for lunch after our appointment. It was so good that when we dropped our dog off this morning we actually went back for breakfast. Going back to the vet again tomorrow morning to get our dog and you guessed it, going back for another pastry and a Cuban Coffee. Seriously don't miss this place!!
This place has amazing Cuban food! Love this little mom and pops corner shop. Yuca fries to die for!
The Cubano sandwich never disappoints , and I love the empanadas they deserve four stars. It is Great for a quick lunch. The employees are lack luster, the outside tables wobbly and that's about it.

Yummmmmm, I would have given 5 stars but I've had several bad experiences with some of their dishes. This establishment is still on my top list of weekend choices however. When you go their and you find your dish, you'll understand

I live right around the corner from this place, so I come here often. I've tried the majority of their sandwiches and appetizers. They are all extremely delicious. I used to go classic Cuban sandwich until I discovered the other sandwiches are even better. I love the lechon sandwich, and my boyfriend loves the croquetas sandwich (which I agree is probably the best sandwich they have). We usually get the aji relleno and the wanna be cuban for appetizers. They are both awesome, but I love the wanna be cuban better (even though it's soy beef, and I am NOT a vegetarian by any  means!) The maduros are also really good. I just think the empanadas are so-so, though. I definitely wouldn't come here for those.  The service is always friendly and usually quick. The only bad experience we've had was on the first nice weather day this year they were super busy, so our order took probably 25-30 minutes longer than normal. They also forgot to give us part of our order. It wasn't a big deal though since it's not normally like that, and they gave us a credit.

COME ON, SHAKE YOUR BODY BABY, DO THE CONGA! I was introduced to this place by my 20-something year old niece. She really knows a lot of great restaurants in the city! We've been here several times over the years. My favorite dish is the Churrasco which is marinated skirt steak and super tender. It is served with garlic sauce, a little parsley, yellow rice and boiled yuca (which is like a potato) con mojo de ajo. If you do not like garlic do not order this dish. My husband always orders the Fricase de pollo which is perfectly prepared with an goluptious of flavors and fall off the bone tender. The vibe is cool with people of all ages. When we came here, I heard the song, "Come on, Shake Your Body Baby, Do the Conga!" I started tapping my foot to the beat of the music. Hey, after a few drinks I really wanted to start a Conga line, but I was afraid I'd get kicked out of the restaurant. Maybe next time I'll get the courage to actually start a Conga line! Oh, but I digress....back to the food.... For starters, we ordered the empanadas (three different kinds) -- chicken, ropa vieja and beef. They don't tell you which one is which so you have to bite into them to find out "which" one is chicken, beef or ropa vieja. We shared the stuffed papa which was perfectly prepared and very, very good. Empanadas are worthy of 4 stars. The stuffed potatoes are 5 stars worthy. To be perfectly honest, I have had much better Cuban comida (food) at other Cuban restaurants in Chicago (for a lot less). Give "El Cubanito" in Logan Square a shot (OMFG, I love their steak and Cuban sandwiches). Also, hit up "Paladar" (Western Ave) or even "Señor Pan (on North Ave, near Western) for tasty Cuban comida. Señor Pan has two locations, but I prefer their North Ave joint. La comida at these places is actually much more delectable with higher quality cuts of meat than here. You're welcome for these tips! We usually bring two bottles of wine. We enjoy Argentinian wines, such as, Malbec or Tempranillo, both pair nicely with meat dishes. Go here early (even if you don't usually eat an early dinner), especially on weekends. We brought along two bottles of Bodegas Graffigna 2012 Centenario Malbec, but any Malbec wine balances nicely with meat dishes. Service is effusive, but incredibly lackadaisical. On weekends, it gets super crazy crowded for dinner. I recommend trying this joint for lunch instead. The wait can be crazy long for dinner service, especially on weekends. It is a small restaurant with indoor and outdoor seating. It can also get very polyphloisboisterous inside!  You may wait up to 30-minutes for your comida, so definitely pop open your bottle of vino and order several appetizers to avoid passing out at your table. The food is flavorful with various Latin herbs and spices. Portions are fine, but not huge. This is a great place for people of all ages (great for small groups, not large).  The outdoor seating fills up quickly in the Summer. Hey, if you do not mind inhaling gas fumes while enjoying your meal then sit outside, by all means!  Parking around here can be a pain in the ass. The inside is really dated. Nothing spectacular. The decor is rather tired, dark, dingy and boring.  Service -- 3 stars (at a turtle's pace) Price-point -- 4 stars Cuisine -- 4 stars Ambiance/Decor -- 3 stars Outdoor patio -- 2 stars (please invest in new tables/chairs) For the best Cuban sandwiches hit up "El Cubanito" or "Paladar" (definitely get the Ropa Vieja here). Also, Cohiba Cuban Cuisine (Broadway, east side, half block north of Diversey) serves outstanding ropa vieja. El Paladar and Cohiba are great spots for a date night with your spouse or for a "First" date. Also, give Señor Pan a shot -- really good spot for lunch or dinner (North Ave location). If you are seeking exceptional and delectable Puerto Rican cuisine, hit up Casa Yari, Juanita's or La Plena. (Read the Yelp reviews if you don't believe me)!

Absolutely DO order the Avocado Salad. It's super tasting, and filling on it's own. I also ordered the Lechon, there were some very tender and moist pieces, but I also got some very dry unappetizing pieces as well. The rice and beans were perfect -- not a fan of the sweet plantains that also come on the side. It's a small space, with just a few countertop seats, and a few tables on their patio. Bathroom is VERY odd, you have to walk to the side of the building, and make sure you lock two doors -- the one from the outside and the one from the kitchen -- and then unlock them when you are finished. Service was perfect. Food was good. I'd definitely come back, but I'd make sure it was a nice enough day so I could sit outside.

This place is awesome. The staff is super friendly, it's good ambience, and the sandwich I got was delicious. Very fresh and so damn tasty. I'm officially addicted to Cubanos now. The empanadas were also really good. I didn't love the spinach one, but the others were delicious. I'll definitely be back.
Excellent Cuban coffee!

What can one say, the food is good, not out of this world but good.  Like a theme restaurant they try to convince you its Key West inside with a run down interior (oh, that was on purpose?) and an unpaved dining patio floor and chairs and tables that rock. But when its 20 degrees outside and there is 3 feet of snow on the sidewalks there is no way you'll believe its Key West.  So food was good, ambiance was something to be ignored.  But the waitstaff was excellent, eager and attentive it made dining there a pleasure.

This location has a small, quick to go or eat in option, but that doesn't take away from the awesome food! The armitage location offers more space for dining in.  I've never had a bad meal here, and I can't leave without getting a cuban espresso!!!

Delicious, just the pick me up I needed for lunch. Casual setting with only 10 stools, its a small and cozy environment. I would recommend take out but there are two locations and this one is a little smaller than the one on Armitage. Now for the food, I ordered the Bistec De Palomilla which is a steak type item with onions, tomatoes, lettuce, some sauce, with I think plantain chips. Great for a light/medium lunch. The sandwich itself was good but a little stiff, my jaw felt like I was working it out cause I had to bite the tough bread, otherwise it went down happily. Not sure what authentic Cuban food is but this one def was tasty. Would recommend.

Approved by my 6 year old. Loved the yucca fries and the croquetta sandwich. Yucca fries had the perfect texture, crisp on the outside and soft and moist inside. I've had dry yucca fries before and they know how to make it perfectly here. Sandwiches are pretty big and come with plantain chips (though some of the chips were cold and soggy), but you will be satisfied. I also got the regular Cubana, it was just ok after trying the croquetta. The Cubana just tastes like a regular ham sandwich you can make at home. The croquetta on the other hand was what I was wanting to experience. Great flavor and texture. Something different for my tastebuds, almost like bbq or balsamic vinegar but not too sour, a little sweet. Tasted so good mm. My daughter said, "this is delicious!.. "  Sounding a bit surprised herself. So my suggestion would be to try the other sandwiches

My first time here and I got the Cuban sandwich. The meat was juicy and flavorful and the pickle outstanding / great crunch! I haven't had a Cuban since a Florida trip years ago! A cute, casual and full of nostalgia place I will go back again!

What an amazing authentic Cuban restaurant from the loud music, decor and just crontrolled happy chaos. We had a group of 20 for a farewell dinner and they took amazing care of us and everything from the not too sweet mango mojito mix to the lechon, empanadas and rojo viejo .... Muy muy Bueno! I will be back

Absolutely will go back!! Had the buffet, and although we loved it, wish we could have ordered off the menu. Service was great. Coffee taste just like you get it in little Havana, Miami. Definitely deserves the five stars.

I called in around 1:30 PM to make an order for pickup and was asked to be put on hold which was fine. I waited...and waited... and waited. I was on the phone for 13 minutes before I thought maybe something happened and decided to hang up and call back. I called back and was asked to once again be put on hold and I asked "why am I being put on hold?"  and explained how I had already waited 13 minutes the first time. I just wanted to know if maybe something was happening to explain the wait. They answered "Hold on one minute, she'll take your order right now." and was put on hold for another 15 minutes before being hung up on. I called back and explained how I had already been put on hold twice and was given the reasoning behind it was that only one order could be manually input at a time. Still confused about the hold but anyway my burrito from Chipotle was delicious.

This place is such a solid place to grab breakfast lunch or dinner. My roommate was seriously craving sandwiches in the morning so we decided to pop by and grab a few to go. I got the Pan Con Lechon which was overall fairly fabulous and satisfied my stomach really well. The slow roasted pork on the inside was really good but on the whole, a little too dry. Also I bit and then spit out about a half inch bone lodged in my pork. The grilled onions on the inside was my favorite part but somehow I didn't notice the shoestring potatoes which were supposed to be there. But like I said, overall, the sandwich was pretty top notch for only $7.  Empanadas. Yes, get them. They are so plump because they're completely stuffed with filling! Plus the outside is fried to a perfect light golden crisp. I don't think you can go wrong with any of the flavors except for my one small warning: the chorizo with goat cheese is overpowered by the taste of the goat cheese. I barely tasted the chorizo, if at all.  Note: This location is extremely tiny inside with maybe about 8-10 seats only. Order to-go for sure unless you don't mind eating alongside people waiting in line. Employees are also super nice here!
Love the chicken grilled sandwich and their hot sauce is amazing.  The horrible and I mean horrible part is that they almost ALWAYS MESS UP take out orders.

Awesome freakin sandwiches! Stopped in around 10am and grabbed a seat in what can virtually be described as a shack with a kitchen . Only about 10 seats inside...but man was it worth it. Tried their Media Noche Sandwich (a Friday Special) as opposed to their Cuban. Fortunately it was a near mirror image and worth every red cent! Tender pork and ham, pickles, plenty of Swiss cheese, and mustard topped off the dish perfectly. Their egg bread was similar to you're more often seen Hawaiian style bread. A side of maraquitas was icing on the cake! It's understandable the hype, and no doubt one of the best Cuban sandwiches in the city. Now I'm looking to check out their other location, I'm sure it's just as great.

Came here on a whim yesterday to discover a tiny shoebox sized restaurant; definitely set up more for deliver and to do orders. The man behind the counter was extremely warm and welcoming and helped me  with the menu when I admitted that I was new to Cuban food. He made some great recommendations, and I always appreciate it when the staff are familiar with the menu. The menu is a tad heavy on fried foods so I probably won't be making this a regular stop, but I will absolutely be coming back for more good food.

Small sister restaurant to the much larger 90 miles on Armitage. Great for lunch- food is AMAZING! And they have some good weekly sandwich specials too that go until 5pm. Work is only 5 mins from here- looks like I found my new favorite lunch spot!

Stumbled across 90 miles during a mid afternoon bout of hunger with the gf. Pleasantly surprised by the small yet inviting atmosphere. Old school Cuban island music playing as you wait to have your order taken. Food was delicious...we ordered the Pan Con Lechon and the Bistec de Palomilla with a side of Yuca con Mojo. If you like garlic, def. order the yuca. Will for sure return for more of this authentic Cuban cuisine.
This place is a gem.  Personal, tasty, lively, memorable...I love it. This is just my type of place. Simple and good with a true touch of hospitality.
Food is overpriced. There are more authentic places out there. Food is ok. Its the only Cuban spot around the area. At least it has a parking lot.

I've tried the other 90 Miles and went to this one for the first time. Very small place but cozy. Friendly staff. Ordered the puerco rostizado again and the salida del sol (early grey tea with mango puree).  Yummmm...tender pork, delicious rice (even the rice is great!), and black beans. The maduros were a bit on the cold side but overall, I really enjoyed the food and service. Would come here again!
We live near by and eat here once every few weeks. Sandwiches are great, I won't waste your time with much other than a recommendation just go there!

Stopped by while running errands...was amazed at how much space the little "shack" had inside.  Ordered the slow cooked pork and it was delicious.  My only issue is not much in the green family on the menu but I will be back and order a salad on the side of my entree.  The staff were very friendly and the place had an energetic vibe that just made me want to smile.  Very reasonably priced food as well.

Get the pork appetizer platter... Deep fried slow cooked chunks of pork... Just be prepared for a nap afterwards. The Cuban is also state of the art.  Small place, great patio, good for a quick bite or take out.

Eh.. It was ok. I got a chorizo cubano I think. It was a chorizo burger pretty much. The burger wasn't bad, either it or the bun was greasy. The sweet plantains were a good compliment since the chips and burger were kind of plain.

Really?!! 4 small itty bitty empanadas for almost $9 I think, heck I don't know how much I paid because they didn't even provided a receipt which I thought was in the bag, no more business from all my family members to you, those empanadas where a joke and one looked like half eaten, never again 90 miles, NEVER!!!

Worth the drive to check this (Clyborne location) restaurant out! I only gave 4 stars because I'd like to go back and try more dishes, but definitely 4 stars for the food. This restaurant was featured on Food Network, but I heard about it after a friend checked it out first. Living in the suburbs I've found that good Cuban food is not as easily accessible. My go-to dish growing up was always the Ropa Vieja.The traditional marinated beef served with rice and my favorite Maduros (fried plantains). The Ropa Vieja was very flavorful and reminded me of the local mom and pop Cuban restaurants I visited with family growing up. The Maduros were not mushy and cooked just right..."al dente" is the best way I can describe them.  Looking forward to going back again.

Awesome place if you are looking to get a taste of the Cuban culture Cubano sandwich best in town give all the empanadas trying to have various different types comes with this garlic sauce vary delicious love the feel of the environment I feel like I'm old cuba music was great and service was awesome highly recommended drop by awesome place for some good Cuban cuisine 5 ***** oh and I forgot to mention it's b_y_o_b you can bring 6 facto back to provide you with a bucket of ice and glasses awesome

The best coffee/caffe con leche in the city with some really good food. I am a very regular customer but unfortunately the service has been terrible lately. The last two times I visited while no one else was in the restaurant I have been ignored for extended periods of time while they stared right at me. In each instance the employees were obviously on the phone arguing with the owner. In my opinion, you should probably put the call on hold while you tend to your patrons.

I recently moved and wanted to try this spot. we got two steak sandwiches, 6 empanadas, rice & beans and it was over $40. The food was on the bland side. I definitely make better beans. The empanadas were pretty good though! Nothing too exciting to keep me running down the block though, unfortunately.

This place is excellent. There is a larger restaurant in Logan Square-this location is more of a shack. But the food is much better-the best really.  Go on a summer afternoon and sit in the ample seating area outside. Take your time, it's great.  Two tips: if you eat hot sauce, eat the home made. It's excellent. And order the Yucca fries with garlic sauce. You cannot go wrong.

BYOB! Food is super super super greasy.  Just not our style.  We went to the smaller location and the vibe was also really meh.  I couldn't wait for my husband to finish his cuban sandwich which was OK, not great, so we could leave.   The kid working the counter was super friendly and helpful when ordering.   If you like Cuban food and are not adverse to a a decent amount of greast maybe try the location with the larger patio in Bucktown.

Right near home and lots of delicious options.  I like the sandwiches more than the plates since I wasn't a huge fan of the beans/rice.  I haven't had a sandwich I didn't like but I'm a big cubano and ropa vieja fan. The goat cheese empanadas are really great, but they've forgotten to give us the sauce that goes with them the last two times :(.  Other than that disappointment, it's a solid option for lunch and dinner.  They also just redid the patio and it looks great!

Sandwiches are good, hardly super cuban, but delicious none the less. However, been coming to this one for a while and the service has just gone completely downhill. Food has been taking FOREVER recently. Today I went in and was greeted by the owner and/or manager behind the counter. He was friendly enough, but let the customer behind me 'cut' because he had phoned his order in. Mind you, he'd called it in, he hadn't paid yet, so they still had to ring him up etc. I've worked in food service, it makes more sense to put my order in and then help this man. ALSO, for those of you who love their house hot sauce, apparently you're supposed to pay 50 cents per hot sauce on to-go orders now. Which is dumb. If i was eating my sandwich there, it would've been complimentary. Just the dumbest. None of his employees ever charge...but they also only give you like a drop of sauce, so I guess that evens out. Basically, used to like to go there. Now it's slow, manager is rude, and they charge for condiments. There's a new cuban place opening up the street on Roscoe...I'm looking forward to it.

I'm a fan of the sandwiches in this place. I'm not a fan of olives, but their sandwiches are so good that I don't even care about the olives. There's only two downsides: they can be a little slow and they're pretty expensive for what's essentially a sub sandwich. Aside from that, it's worth a visit every now and then if you're in the neighborhood.

use to love going here but i had a bad experience this guy working the counter wanted to assume something was wrong with my credit card and i told him had this problem before with your machine just his attitude i will not be coming back.

I've wanted to try this restaurant for a while but was scared away by the tiny size and the crowds.  I went at an odd time (between lunch and dinner) on a Saturday afternoon to avoid the crush.  I was really pleased with all the veggie options-not something Cuban food is usually known for.  I ordered 2 empanadas, the black beans and the plantains.  I thought the spinach empanada was delicious if a bit skimpy in size.  The black beans were good but, as I'd read in some other reviews, not overly flavorful and the portion was not generous for the price.  The plantains were delicious.   Wondering about that other empanada?  I was eating alone and wanted to get some more soda so I left my book and food (1/2 a bowl of beans and an uneaten empanada and an empty plate where the amazing plantains had been) on my table on the patio and went inside to get a refill.  I came back in less than a minute and the plates had been cleared!  A table which had been empty for at least 15 minutes still had a stack of dirty plates on it but mine had been promptly cleaned.  My empanada was replaced after I complained but what does a gal have to do-leave a note on her book saying "Touch this empanada and die?".

I have been a big fan of dinners drive-ins and dives on the food network and say this place on an episode. So being in Chicago I made the trip out to try it for two reasons, one cause guy went there and two because I've never had true authentic Cuban food. 90 mile Cuban cafe is just that! I had their chicken dinner special with all the fixings and is was amazing. The chicken cooked to perfection in a way that screams Cuba and the rice, black beans, and plantains where the right side for this dish. They also serve dessert empanadas that are too good to not leave without having at least one. The place is small with seating outside so consider getting an order for take out but if you get the chance to sit outside on a weekend they normally have a live band outside playing Cuban street music and it adds a real touch of the forbidden island that is so close to Florida. I will be going back and I'll be going back often to try everything this little place has to offer.

Outstanding food - the best Cuban food I've enjoyed outside of south Florida. Be prepared for a very casual experience - most of the seating is outdoors (aside from some stools inside, which doesn't seem all that comfortable), so either plan on visiting on a nice day or taking your order to go.

90 Miles makes one of the best Cubano sandwhiches I've had in Chicago.  The meat is melt-in-your-mouth goodness.  The plantain chips are great.  I also love the empanadas.  The guava and cheese is an interesting, but delicious combination.  This location is no frills with a small eat-in bar and outdoor patio.  We've also ordered catering (from the Logan Square location) for one of our parties.  Everyone raved about the food.  Even the Veggie sandwhich was delicious. I've recently discovered they offer all you can eat roasted pig with sides and  dessert every Thursday from 6-10pm for $15.  What??!!  I'll be back for that.

Had the Cuban sandwich which was good, fresh bread and actual roasted pork and thick cut ham.  Plaintain chips that came with sandwich were kind of stale though and didn't have much flavor. Would come back to try the other specialties.

After being burned by the 2 hour queue length at Hot Doug's, my bladder, stomach and feet were not going to put up with a wait that long! Luckily, this lil' gem was close by and so I made my way there. Had the Masitas de Puerco appetizer which Dollface and I tore apart at home as it was awesome, it is filling enough for 2 and we won't have to worry about being attacked by vampires anytime soon!! I ordered 2 Cuban sandwiches of the steak and pork variety, both delicious. I think I may try to do the menu challenge I haven't been disappointed yet.  I don't quite understand the people on some of the reviews that complain about the service and wait time, it takes as long as it takes and the staff are very pleasant. And the prices are reasonable. Some people....

We've had lunch from here twice now and nothing has been disappointing. All the sandwiches we've had ropa vieja, lechon, frita cubana, and bistec sandwich were all equally amazing. The empanada and the masitas de puerco appetizer were delicious as well. You will REEK of garlic but garlic is good for your heart and keeps the demons away ;) Oh and my husband hates bananas but he can't get enough of plantains from here. Can't wait to eat my way through the rest of the menu and try their other location as well for a sit in dinner. YUM!!!

This place is a hidden GEM on the corner of Clybourn and Oakley. We frequent 90 Miles on a weekly basis. The empenadas are the best! The yuca fries come with this amazing olive oil and garlic dip. Everyone there is very friendly. They just made upgrades to enhance their outdoor patio, which we love sitting at! Dog friendly, outside :)
Great food, great service.  They do a good job staying true to the Cuban genre... A fun destination restaurant if you're near the Chicagoland area.

Two weeks ago I went to 90 Miles on Clybourn and experienced an awkward situation. I was kidding around with one of the employees about forgetting my hot sauce. The owner Alberto was there and made a rude comment to the employee "That's why I forgot to give you a raise." As a customer what am I suppose to think? 1. You don't care about your employees 2. You don't value his efforts to make your customers experience at your restaurant great and fun 3. You probably don't care about your customers either. Couple of weeks ago I went to the 90 miles location in Logan Square. I wrote about my horrible experience and the response that I got from the incident was the following: "Good Afternoon Patty M., I would like to personally apologize for the experience that you had with us recently. I have been informed by my Management team of this incident and we are hastily working on ways to make sure that this never happens again. We take all reviews very seriously and again I would like to sincerely apologize for the experience you recently had with us. Thank you for your time, Raul Soto Floor Manager raul@90milescubancafe.com (773)227-2822" I have been going to 90 Miles for years and have seen many great employees like the one mentioned above; Yuri, Clay, Leigh, Myriam, Manny, Jordan, etc. If you consider it the food is way over priced and in the recent year has lost the quality that it once had. I've had better from 90 Miles and yes they might be updating there menu but it won't mean much if its not great.

Pretty tasty. Some unique menu items, some standard, but there is definitely an effort being made to serve quality dishes.  Kind of high-priced, which might be due to the local market: working professionals who prefer to spend on take-out than cook. Indoor seating is a high seats at a counter.

I enjoy Cuban sandwiches and have tried them at other Cuban places. Their sandwiches are pretty good.  I use to work near the location. I have stopped for lunch with co-workers. I have not had any issues with the food but a couple of times my co-workers got sick.  Recently, decided to drive by with my young child. I ordered the ropa vieja sandwich. My child had a couple of bites of the sandwiches. In the evening my child got the stomach flu followed by pneumonia. We do not know the cause of the sickness.  I enjoy the sandwiches from this place and have never been sick from them. However, the probability of co-workers and my child getting sick and having this restaurant to be a common connection makes me wonder about the quality of management and preparation of the food from this place. I have enjoyed the place but will not be returning.

This resto was on my list purely because of the reviews. I don't generally crave Cuban food and this place did not up my interest. I'm not sure why it's so well-reviewed when mostly most of our food was so dry, we had to ask for sauce. It was also incredibly loud and this getting-to-be-old lady wasn't happy that we had a hard time hearing each other.

LOVED IT! Pass it all the time and finally stopped for lunch. It's a tiny spot but I found the food to be fresh and tasty. My fish sandwich with peppers was so satisfying! Definately want to try more of the menu. :}

Poor Service. Overpriced.  Every time I go in here, I swear I'm never going back. If it wasn't so close to me I would have only went once. Since I can see it from my window I think to myself, "what the hell... I'm starving... it probably wasn't that bad." It is.  Every time I go, the person at the front is rude or short with us, the order ALWAYS takes way too long, and there's just too many other places that serve the same caliber of fare with better price and service. I just don't see what the love affair is with this place... I guess that's what you get when Guy Fierri or Anthony Bourdain stop in.

Due to the size of this location, 90 miles is more of a summer destination. It's nice to sit outside with a byob when the weather cooperates. My go to sandwich is the media noche. Favorite thing on the menu, hands down, is the avocado salad. It's literally just sliced avocado, lemon vinaigrette, topped with salt and pepper. Always fresh. Love the mariquitas, but expect to smell like garlic for at least a day. A meal for 2 usually runs us about $25-$30.
I've had a better Cubano sandwich at Cafeteria Marianao, on Milwaukee Ave close to California.

Delicious! And the music completes the food experience!!! Que rico!!!  Try anything! It is ALL GOOD.  And sit and enjoy inside- BUT BEWARE only about 4 people and a midget will comfortably on site.  It is not a place to bring a party to and sit-- but if you happen to stay, enjoy reading the walls of history!  Oh- make sure you try the desserts!!! Mmmmm mmmm goooooood!
Wonderful!  Great tasting authentic Cuban food.   Just as good if not better than any Cuban I've had in southern Florida.

I have been coming here for almost a year. The steak sandwiches are delicious!! They have chimichurri sauce which gives it that unique flavor. Definitely give this place a try!  There's two locations, if you want to dine in I recommend the 2540 W Armitage spot. The one on Clybourne Ave is quite small but it's also great. They both have a Patio sitting..

This place is walking distance so it's a favorite of mine for that reason and because of the Lechon sandwich. Cubans do pork very well! I usually stick with the Lechon sandwich and a handful of Empenadas 9my favorite is the Chorizo) You can either call your order in or just order at the counter. Obviously there is a little wait if you order at the counter, but the place has a charm to it since it is so small, but has 5-6 stools and a bar area to eat and it's covered with newspaper clippings and ads from cuba/florida. Just a solid place to get great food with a compelling atmosphere.
The ropa vieja was very good as was the Palomina Steak and the fried plantains. Seating is limited and there are no restrooms, but the food comes out quick so one is able to get in and out.

I been here several time and almost every time I've come here I have to wait an extreme long time to get my food even if it's take out. The most I had to wait while already seated was an 1hour before I was told roast pig was out.    The kitchen is to small to take care of all the people that come in.
Had a pleasant experience. The food was absolutely delicious and the staff was nice.

I arranged to have my friend's bachelorette party dinners here (first of 2), and walking in I loved the atmosphere.  It's dark, loud and festive -- perfect for our group of 10 ladies. Even though I had a reservation that I made months in advance, we ended up waiting 20-30 minutes, and there's not much room to wait, even in the waiting room! In addition to prosecco, we brought rum to make mojito cocktails with.  We ordered a ton of apps and entrees to share.  Empanadas, Tamales, Mariquitas, The Churrasco, Surf & Turf, Fricase de Pollo, Ropa Vieja and Veggie Entree.  Even after sharing, we had so much leftover food.  We decided to skip dessert as we already had other plans for it.  I'd like to come back with a smaller group next time and maybe sit outside.  Overall, great little BYOB spot!

Their steak sandwich is amazing. That's all I get there. While it is a small place and seating can be tough during peak lunch hours, it is a place I try to go to at least once a month. A great find with fantastic food.

I was so excited to try out this place since so many people had recommended it. I ordered the Bistec de Pollo for take-out with the rude person at the register. The inside of the cafe was disgusting and definitely not appetizing. So glad I was taking it home to eat, but it also made me wonder what the kitchen looked like. As for the food...it was the most bland chicken I have ever had. It made me wonder why I didn't just throw some chicken in the oven and call it a day. Sides consisted of plain white rice and beans that were nothing to write home about. A very underwhelming experience.
It was ok.. Nothing out of this world .. Bad service no restroom, crowded and Greasy food.. Came to Chicago to try new foods and this was definitely not good.

This place has by far the best cuban food I've ever had. You need to try their breakfast sandwich with plantains and banana chips... They have great tasting cafe con leche, and when it comes to dinner, everything is amazing.

What a disappointment.. Ropa vieja was un-flavorful & wasn't impressed with their empanadas either..after a $500 food tab we were politely kicked out because they said they needed to accommodate more people.. It was almost 11pm!! And we spent $500 solid dollars not including the 20% unearned tip.. Not attentive at all.. First and last time there..
Always one of a regular spot for lunch or for cafe con leche in the mornings with bread and butter.

I work at a Latin American bar and I wish our empanadas taste half as good as these do. It makes me sad I can't have one right this very minute. They're stupid good. And to build my argument, I have had different empanadas--Argentinean, Jamaican, Puerto Rican, Salvadorian, Cuban. I will happily choose these as the supreme winner.
Delicious food and very friendly staff.  Empanadas and the papa relleno are my favorites.  Very small inside space, which is all counter seating, but fantastic for takeout.

I love the look and feel of this place - Chicago needs more neighborhood spots like this! (My husband blames LEYE for this but we won't get into all that right now)  90 Miles is a tiny shack with a friendly, authentic, neighborhood vibe to it. We were there on a cold and rainy day, but I can imagine the outdoor seating in the summer is a nice touch. Right off the bat, the employees were friendly and welcoming. We weren't sure what to order, so they walked us through the menu and gave us some pointers.  We were both extremely satisfied with our delicious orders. We got the yucca frites, empanadas, and two sandwiches - and everything was fantastic! The accompanying sauces were great too, especially the house-made hot sauce. I will definitely be back to tackle my way through the menu.  The location may be inconvenient for some, but the free parking lot helps! Definitely make your way out here, it's worth a visit!

This place is just a little shack in Roscoe Village but do not let the looks deceive you. The food is very good and reasonable priced.  This is going to be one of my winter favorites.Since it is so small, it was very warm inside, the Cuban newspaper clippings on the wall and the music, I almost wanted to enjoy a cigar after my food.It felt that right and was that authentic.  Going to be back soon for a good meal!

I visited 90 Miles from Cuba last weekend and was having a delicious meal with friends- but half-way through the meal, one of us noticed out of the corner out of their eye that right above us hung a noose- yes a big rope noose.
