What? We asked the waiter what it was about and he said it was a Cuban piece of art, expressing the shortness of life. It made our stomachs turn. It was really creepy. I couldn't shake the creepy feeling all day, and called the restaurant later to ask to speak to the manager. I was informed that several visitors had raised the issue of the noose, remarked that in the US, nooses have only one, and a horrible, racist connotation, but that the owner had refused to take it down. I don't plan on going back, which is too bad because the food was great. But seriously, man. That's just completely insensitive to clientele, black and white alike.

I loved this place until the owner stopped being there all the time. The cashiers are rude. I used to love their steak sandwich but it's so expensive and the bread changed :( .. I rather go Mariano's for a 3 dollar REAL Cuban sandwich.

I was there for the first time with a group of people who were ready to try Cuban food, and the same time to practice a little bit of Spanish. Food was great, service was excellent, and we had such an awesome time.

I had a Cuban brother in-law way back in the 80s when I lived in Florida, and their family had a couple of restaurants. Classic stuff, the Cuban Sandwich is, just one bite and I was hooked for life. 90 Miles is a counter joint, but it's great for lunch. Yellow mustard, dill pickle slices, swiss cheese, ham, pork all pressed on a roll, I usually opt for the Media Noche, which is slightly sweeter. They've got another location which is great for dinner (can you say ROAST PORK?)

If the place is listed until being open until 9pm, but won't seat at 8:47pm, perhaps the hours should be adjusted to read "seating until..."  Just say'n.  Love the food, love the restaurant regardless.

Great Food, Very Fresh. I tried almost every sandwich and they're the best. I tried almost every dinner on the menu and it's phenomenal. Their food is better than Cuba. And I spent a lot of time in Cuba due to my government job. Their café con Leche is the best in the world. All other Cuban restaurants in Chicago should just shut down and move. They don't stand a chance against These people

I have mixed reviews about this place, likely because I'm Cuban and have high expectations.  Anyways, the food here is pretty decent.  Have had the ropa vieja, but have noticed both times it is a bit dry. Have also had the empanadas, which were okay.  The biggest disappointment was the cafe con leche...could have been just because they put way too much milk or don't use Bustelo.  Not sure.  Regardless this place is decent and very convenient with there take out location so will likely be back.
Pretty cool little place; but I have to agree with others... The ropa vieja dinner could have been more flavorful.

What happened? I haven't been there for a couple of months. We usually go there for their excellent Cuban "breakfast" sandwich with the works. That means Swiss cheese, diced ham/onions and maduros.  Went there this week for the breakfast sandwich. This "is" a hardy sandwich which can feed two people. A generous proportion of egg, ham, cheese and onion folded over. A thick slice of maduro goes on top of the folded over egg tortilla and placed inside a warm toasted french bread.  Did I say "is" regarding this sandwich: how about was. First of all the employee turn around at the front counter is like the deli at the Roscoe Village Marianos's. New body every time I visit. Okay, so I called my order in and asked for a breakfast sandwich with everything including maduros. When I opened my sandwich I see they have given my a side order of maduros instead of adding it in the sandwich. No problem. I can put the maduros inside the sandwich myself, plus the side order gave me three slices instead of the one slice I would've gotten inside the sandwich. Or should I say, half the sandwich it used to be. OMG! It felt light right away. It was half the portion of egg it used to be, a hint of ham, I'll say shadows of ham and the bread was not toasted. I can't speak about the rest of the menu except for their fish soup. I tried and it not good. Months later I gave the soup a second chance and it was the same. That was the end of that menu item for me.  I hope this was just a bad day, but know that inconsistency is a major turn off for any restaurant. Somewhere down the line, I'll try the breakfast sandwich again on a "not so hungry day" and see what happens. I will surely let you know.

3.5 stars! I really liked the tofu sandwich I had but my friends chicken bistec dinner plate was not as good. Just some boiled chicken that didn't have enough spice IMO. still def worth a try and I'll go back for the sandwich!

Absolutely love this place! I practically grew up on Calle Ocho and it has been difficult to find another Cuban restaurant that can come close to it. Authentic ingredients. Friendly staff! This place is delicious! If you're looking for delicious, authentic Cuban cuisine come to this restaurant!

I don't know why I think this place needs another review. It's awesomeness is pretty clear. But I thought I'd take a minute to express my joy at having recently moved within a 120 second walk of 90 miles. Would it be wrong to just order like 30 empanadas and five sides of sweet plantains and gorge myself to the point of regurgitation? No, I don't think so. The ropa vieja is so f-ing good. Yes I have had the Cubano sandwich (mostly because it is one of my favorite sammiches) and yes obviously it is amazing. And my mission is to eat the entire menu, but it's so hard because I can't help but fill up on the empanadas! If you haven't been here there is an emptiness in your soul that you won't even know about until you fill it... with sweet sweet plantain love.

this is definitely a place that took the tv show exposure straight to their heads.  the food takes way too long to make and they act like these items are special, if anything this slop is glorified college street food. the service is plain bad and all the food is over priced ($4.50) to add avocado to a salad, get real. on one occasion the cashier (hipster) hung up on me when i asked if i could order the special and take it to go, when i called back she said "give me one moment". i didnt appreciate that if i didnt want to spend $15.00 on lunch and wanted to save by ordering the special, i had to eat it in their cummy, humid, stick, and dirty cafe, on a little bitty shelf for a table. this place is sub par in every way imaginable, woulnt recommend this place to a bum that stole my wallet.
Great food.  Definitely worth the trip.  The beans and rice were great.  Food was as expected.  Has more of a laid back diner appeal.  Not very fancy but the food delivers.  Great for a nice bite.

I love the simplicity of this little place.  I got the Cubano and fries and really liked them. I hadn't ever had a Cuban before so I don't have much frame if reference but I will say it was very tasty.  Very little indoor seating, but they have a fantastic little patio next to their mural.

I have been going here (take out) for years, and up until recently would have given it 5 stars. I love their food - and their coffee. Lately, though - the last 3 visits, in fact - I have been dissatisfied with the service.  It takes too long to get even just a cafe con leche and a few empanadas, a typical order for me. They have forgotten the dipping sauce, even forgot to give me my coffee until reminded, and the coffee aroma and after-taste almost seemed like an alcoholic beverage the last time. What could cause that? I will still go here, but I am disappointed with the current staff. Maybe I will try the full-sized restaurant on Armitage next time.

90 miles has two distinct locations...do not confuse the two this (the roscoe village) location is an itty bitty little shack...with a small but adequate for its size parking lot it has counter seating for a select few inside and a patio that seats about 30 everyone orders inside and tho there is no waiter service, they will bring your food out to you it is byob but unlike the armitage location this 90mi does NOT offer pitchers to mix your own sangria, and with that lack of fruit on the side also comes a lack of a cork fee had ropa vieja sandwich which was not my fav due to not quite shredded meat and a lacking in flavor everything else; others had empanadas which they said were really tasty

TIP: they close at NINE PM NOT EIGHT PM yelp has it wrong.  Biked there last night at 8:30- very bikeable area.  Love the lime-infused water. Had the deep fried pork medallions covered in minced garlic, served with thinly sliced red onion which add a wonderful bit of zest, plantains, and beans and rice.  The meat is wonderful and fatty, the plantains and red onion were nice sweet/tangy touches.  Wish I had something lighter with it (more plantains, as it came with three, or some veggies) but still a solid dish.  Also had the more affordable ($7) ropa vieja sandwich: crisp but chewy cuban bread, extremely tender stewed meat with green chiles and just enough tomato sauce to flavor the bread.  Served with addictive slightly spicy plantain chips.   Quite good!

Went to 90 miles with two friends of mine. I had the oxtail dish and it was absolutely delish. I've been dreaming about it ever since. My husband and friend had the ropas vieja and it was good but pretty dry, probably wouldn't order it again if we went. We also had three empanadas: ropas vieja, shrimp, and chorizo. Chorizo was delicious, shrimp was pretty weird but tasted good, and ropas vieja was the same as the dish - dry.  Love that this place is byob, we made one of our wines into their sangria and it was great. Will definitely come back here, especially for the oxtail. YUM
An authentic trip in flavor! Check out my full review here:  thebuckwheater.com/90-mi…

Friendly staff, great ambiance on the patio - tiki torches and all - and delicious food! Tried the empanadas, my favorite being the chorizo and goat cheese, and the cubano sandwich. My only complaint would be that the congris seemed pretty dry. In comparison, my dinner companions each had a bowl of black beans with a side of rice that looked moist and yummy. I would ask for that next time instead. I look forward to my next visit!

Incredible!  This place is amazing.  BYOB.  Enjoy this place on a warm afternoon or evening.  Ask them what their special is and order it!  They have mushrooms, stuffed peppers, chorizo, empanadas.  Enjoy and don't be that guy that only orders the Cubano.  Be open to trying the best.  Have fun.

My friend decided to take me hear for lunch had to take my son with me who has food allergies . The waiter was rushing our order I told him my son is allergic to garlic please make his steak plain with no seasoning. When we got are order my son took a bite and said it had garlic and it sure did a ton he re fired the order and the second steak had some garlic pieces on it too! I didn't even bother telling him again just got our check and left. Within 24 hours my 5 year old son had an allergic reaction vomiting painful belly pain hard stomach the works. I barely go to restaurants for this reason but thought what the heck lets go eat um never again.

First off, the food is delicious and the atmosphere is amazing. This place is great for groups. No one in the group was unsatisfied or hungry by the end, so everything on the menu is equally good. The only downside I would say is even though they are byob, the mojito pitcher is a little expensive for just the non-alcoholic parts. Besides that, I've already been there a few times and I'll keep coming back.

My wife and I came here with high expectations.  We left pretty disappointed with the food.  It may be because this was our first time having Cuban food and didn't order the right combinations of things on the menu.  We started with the Tostones Rellenos and when it arrived at our table, it smelled very good.  However, it was very bland.  It tasted nothing like how it smelled like.  My wife got the Ropa Vieja because our fellow yelpers recommended it while I got the Puerco Rostizado.  The presentation of the dish looked boring.  It came very quick so I don't know if they rushed it or what... but it tasted just as how it looked.. boring.  It just wasn't flavorful as I thought it would be.  We did come on a Friday night where it was snowing in the middle of April.  Yeah, I am trying to find excuses for this place. I was just expecting more.  Here's another thing about their staff. I called to check if they take reservations on a Friday.  They said no because they are a small restaurant.  I understood and asked about how long the wait may be for two if I arrived in 10 minutes.  They weren't that busy yet so they assured the wait wouldn't be long. I thanked them and hanged up.  When I arrived 10 minutes later, I was greeted and asked if "I had reservations for the evening". What the heck? I brushed it off since they were able to seat me right away.  Also, our waitress was very soft spoken and that didn't help with the loud music playing in the background. I don't mind the music, they can choose whatever best describe the personality of the restaurant, but it felt like they were trying to mix a bar/club with a restaurant with the music.  I may give this another try again one day and I do hope to update my review for more stars but for now... this place was "blah" for me.

Overpriced, dismal portions, and took too long for order.  The food is priced as if it was in a busy and popular area, but it's in the middle of nowhere on Clybourn with no other decent places around.  It was tasty, but not satisfying.

I just had lunch there last week  and the dough of the empanadas was undercooked and then I ordered dessert which also contained a hair gross! I was very disappointed.  Another issue the waiter had something black under his nails which I hope as only dirt.
Delicious Cuban cuisine, excellent customer service, reasonable pricing, great to dine out doors in the summer.  No complaints...

I was there six months ago and it was great, good food and good service.  Today I took a friend there for first time to dine in. The place was very busy.  I placed the order in a reasonable amount of time but the food order took FOREVER!  Finally after 45 minutes I was told that my order was accidently placed behind the others.  After 1 hour the 2 sandwiches finally came out.  The food was good but I will never return due to the slow poor service.

I reviewed their other location and basically its exactly the same thing so below I will copy and paste my review.....I did deduct a star because this location is so small there is no room to even wait for your food, annnnnd the few times I've been here they've been out of something including bread for sandwiches!!!! WTF?! Let's begin with the fact that I'm Cuban and I love ALL types of food Cuban food especially! I know what  I'm talking about when it comes to the eating out experience, and I'm always confused about my feelings after leaving this place. A few signature items keep me going back. For the type of food and portions you are given I believe 90 Miles is grossly over priced! I feel that their prices are so high that I'm almost insulted every time I'm given my total. For a good sandwich and some good appetizers and snacks I really recommend this place, but for a full Cuban course this is NOT the place.  *Pro: The sandwiches are pretty damn good. My favorite item on the menu is the Frita Cubana (which basically is a Cuban burger). The frita here is better then any I've had even in Miami!  *Con: THE PRICE! The sandwiches don't come with sides unless you are eating in and I believe their average price per sandwich is about $7 and up. Just recently I went and purchased 2 sandwiches one side 2 drinks and 2 pastries....my total was about $30 which for a Cuban lunch is ridiculously over priced.  I've been to plenty of Cuban restaurants in my day and 90 Miles on average charges about $5 more then other Cuban restaurants in the area for the same meals and actually smaller portions. I believe this place targets the American consumers (young white trendy hipsters/yuppies) and this is why they get away with these type of prices. In the summer I went once and was charged $20 for 2 milkshakes and 4 pastries! It is really difficult to come by good Cuban pastries, and I wont knock the ones they sell here they are good and fresh but cost $2-$2.50 each...**** Side note a little hole in the wall place called Latin American Bakery on Fullerton sells AMAZING Cuban pastries also guava filled for .75 cents each**** Do you understand what I mean about the price now?! Overall the food here is good and some things on the menu like the frita Cubana can only be found here; but the prices are high and the portions are small :(
Awesome sandwiches and atmosphere. I just wished I would have gone sooner.

I want to start my review by saying I have been to 90 Miles several since they opened.  I have always had a great experience until today. We walked it to see a crowded dining room.  That's fine because the place is tiny.  It was a struggle to place our order because the cashier didn't understand the menu.  He didn't know the difference between ropa vieja and lechon asado.  We had to explain it to him.   After we placed our order we waited in the small dining room being surrounded by several diners that were done eating, but hanging out with their coats piled on the counters.  When our food did arrive it was packaged as  a carry out order.  We ordered out meals to dine in!  When we explained this to the young lady she handed us the bag and told us that she would get us silver wear.  Frustrated, we chose to leave.  Once we go home -- THE ORDER IS WRONG!  I don't know what they gave us but it's not rope vieja or lechon asado.   I will absolutely go back to 90 Miles, but not this location.

What a great little dive with the nicest most quiet place to eat outside on a breezy summer day, or inside this Cuban Tiki Hut. Take your food to go, just go! My favorite is the Cubano and Mariquitas. Their strawberry shake is super light and refreshing as well. One of the best independent places I've been to for the best Cuban food EVAR!!! (And it's cheap too.)

After reading so much about this in different newspapers and magazines over the years, I was expecting a lot.  I came for some sandwiches and was a bit disapointed.  The food is ok, but I think cafecito has better quality sandwiches.  I had the Cubano media noche here along with some other sandwiches I tried and they were just ok.

DO NOT GO TO THE CLYBOURN LOCATION!!!  Why would anyone want to eat at a place that tells you to walk to a gas station to use the restroom?  The food is good, the coffee is better,  just go to a different location.  This place should not be allowed to operate if they have indoor seating (albeit tiny) and outdoor seating yet no access to a restroom.  Also, it is hilarious that this is listed as kid friendly as my child had an accident upon being refused access to a restroom.  Very classy.

Poor delivery guy, the order was messed up and he didn't have any change. I called ahead and told the guy taking my order I only have a $20. Enjoy that  $10 tip dude, not ordering delivery again. Fail.  Smoothie was bland, didn't come with a straw.  I've dined in before and had a pleasant experience, but I will stay away from delivery. Too much poor communication in-house, apparently.
Really good empanadas and cubanos. Great atmosphere looks authentic like you are in Cuba and attentive staff.

I was there for lunch and loved the decor, the atmosphere is very relaxing (have to try dinner yet). Service could be quicker as were we the only table there for lunch. It took a good half an hour for a couple of sandwiches. My opinion as five star, three diamond Chef. Food lacked personality and flavor I understand this is cocina criolla but can be presented better and just about anyone can do the rice and beans in any Latin style foods, they yet have think outside the rice and beans and show other options. I would recommend this place for the atmosphere but I am not convinced about the food. For a real Cuban cuisine experience try la unica market on Devon ave.

This location is very small but it's perfect if you just want to stop in and have a quick bite. We started off with the empanadas and we tried 3 different ones. I liked the ropa vieja the best! And the cuban sandwich was huge, I could only eat half. The price is right here too... very inexpensive!

Pricey, but hopefully delicious bistec get in mah belly!  I stopped here one day after dropping my dog off at the pet hospital next door. I grabbed the bistec sandwich. It tasted soo good!! I can't wait to go back and try other goodies offered here. I will most likely go to the one on Armitage though since they have more indoor seating than the location on clybourn.

Absolutely perfect. Great ambience. Pumping salsa music. Got the ropa vieja & bistec sandwich. Some tostones, maduros, switched out the rice&beans with congri, and some jupiña and materva to cool off. Hidden gem. Will definitely be back.
I was underwhelmed. Maybe the hype set em up for failure.

I absolutely LOVE the chicken sandwich here!  The quality of meat is amazing, the bread is so fresh, and the plantains that come with it are the perfect side!  I've been coming here for years, and it is one of my favorite spots in Chicago!

I can't remember the last time I was somewhere with service as good as 90 miles. Although we went there before the lunch crowd entered, the server was attentive without being overbearing. He knew the menu fairly well and gave suggestions. The Media Noche sandwich was good but not great. The Steak sandwich was very good and stood up on its own without the condiments. The strawberry milkshake was as good as any milkshake i''ve ever had. You also get the option of ordering without milk to make it more refreshing. I wanted the flan, but decided we ordered enough. I hope to be able to get the chance to go back.

its AIGHT, not that great I thought, had a bday party here for a buddy, its BYOB which is cool, but I was not that impressed with the full cooked pig (which we got) I even ate the snout and eyeballs. Those were good, but the meat, it needed to be jucier. like put in a sauce or something, I wanted to like this place, and a lot of the other stuff looked delish, I may return and try something else.

Pretty good Cuban food here. The food at this place is tasty, however I find the food  not as flavorful as some of the other Cuban restaurants I've dined in and the portions are average (one entree probably will not to fill a 6' guy's appetite).   We had the Ropa Vieja and roast pork. Both dishes are good and tasty. The pork is tender but not very flavorful. The beef of the ropa vieja is tasty but not as tender and flavorful as could be.  The service is excellent, very nice and attentive waiters and staff. Price is a bit pricey compared to similar ethnic restaurants of this type.

I'm torn between giving 4 or 5 stars here; I'm no connoisseur when it comes to Cuban food, but I've been here 3 times and each time has been great. It's a cozy & little spot, a bit rustic but clean. I suppose sitting there, you could imagine actually being in Cuba. Maybe. Servers are pleasant & helpful. First time, I had a Cubano sandwich w/smashed plantains instead of bread, they were easy on the condiments, & all the flavors strike a perfect balance. 2nd time, I had the ox tail stew. If you've never had ox tail, you don't know what you're missing, I don't think it's possible to make bad ox tail. Theirs was in a rich, tomato-y savory stew, a bit more pepper-heat would have been nice, but regardless, along w/the sweet plantains & rice & black beans, was wholly satisfying. Finally, I had the Guajillo sandwich, garlicky grilled beef on smashed plantains. The quality of the beef was good, flavorful & tender. This one was a little oily, probably from both the meat & the plantains, but it was still delicious, I finished it w/out pause. Maybe not for calorie-counters, but that's not me. The sandwiches are a great bargain, a great lunch can be had here for under $9. Dinners are a bit more, but well worth the price for the quality, care in preparation, and portion size. Overall, I'll be back for sure, w/high expectations!

Not much I can add to the reviews this place already has, but I'll try. I came here to grab some lunch for take out. Upon walking in, we were greeted by a super nice woman who was very helpful. I'd never been there before, so I asked her what some of their best sandwiches were. She recommended the Cubano and the Bistec. I decided to go with the Cubano. It was just the right mix of delicious bread, meat, pickle, cheese, and mustard. I was asked if I wanted to try their hot sauce, so I took it on the side. It was hot, but not burn your mouth hot, and I dipped my sandwich in the sauce before each bite. Simply delicious. I also tried some of the empanadas - 3 for $6.95. I got the chorizo and cheese, ropa vieja, and guava and cheese. They came with a sort of fresh salsa. My favorite was the chorizo and cheese. This place was great and I'm looking forward to my next trip there.
Small/tiny place on Clybourn in Roscoe village.  Went on a Monday for lunch.  Had the ropa vieja which was excellent.  Can't wait to go back to try something else.
Cubano was delicious and I really loved their spicy sauce. Looking forward to coming back to try the other sandwiches and the empanadas

I have a love hate relationship with this place. I was reluctant to go thinking, it wouldn't have many vegetarian options.  I was so wrong, they have so many vegetarian and vegan options, it was hard for me to decide on what to get.  I asked for suggestions.  The tall scruffy guy behind the counter was super welcoming and nice(but not to the point of annoyance) and very knowledgable. The tofu sandwich is incredible.  The tofu was firm and cooked to a perfect texture.  I don't know how they made the sauce, but I'd steel the recipe if I could.    The veggie empanada was small for two bucks, but pretty good.  I'm loving their hotsauce.  I wasn't expecting it to be so flavorful and unique.  I just have two problems with this place.  1. I wish they were open a little later.  They always just closed by the time This place crosses my mind.  2. Everything is about 15-20% more than I want to pay.  I would be here much more often if it was a lil cheaper.  Or if there portions were slightly bigger.

Awesome.  Love the ambience.  Service was on point.  And the food was quickly prepared and excellent!  Parking is at a premium near this location, but can be found.    We live in Orlando and have access to Cuban food daily.  I was very pleased that 90 Miles tasted and looked the same, if not better, than some of the food I've had in Miami.  I really like that its BYOB.  Everyone there was having great time enjoying drinks with friends and family.  The decor reminded me of a few Cuban shops in South Beach.  Highly recommended. The goat cheese empenada...delcious! Puerco Rostizado - oh my freaking goodness!  Sweet, savory, succulent.  Definitely a favorite.

Heard so much and so excited to try this place - sandwich good and liked the empanadas but not the "HOLY Sh** this place is awesome" feeling. Would go back for sure but not planning any special trips anytime soon!

Went here last night because I was craving the warm, delicious goodness that only a pressed-sandwich could bring. I ended up disappointed because my Cubano had the two measliest slices of meat... I was so surprised by the lack of protein, I kept opening the Cuban to check. And they had raised their prices. What gives? $6.95 for toasted bread and not much else!? I don't think so.

Went there for dinner on a Saturday night.  Place was packed, food was good, but it was horribly noisy with very low lighting.   A great place to go if you don't want to converse with your companion (s) or see your food.

90 Miles is known for their Cuban sandwiches -- and realistically, their sandwiches are good, but I wasn't able to differ it from other cuban sandwiches I've had in the past.  But what sets 90 Miles apart is their amazing oxtail.  I got their oxtail dinner special during lunch (it was a bit pricy, around $20) -- it was really tender, fall off the bone.    On our way out, we couldn't help ourselves and ordered their empanadas to go and they were delicious!

Great food as always. I asked the guy behind the counter what type of empanadas he recommended and he convinced me to try the chorizo and cheese and guava and cheese. Both were AMAZING.  I'd never had chorizo or guava before, so I was completely relying on my faith in his pallet, and he didn't lead me astray. I got 2 chorizo and cheese empanadas and 1 guava and cheese empanada. I think it was about $6 for the 3. The outer shell of the empanadas were crispy, delicious, and cooked perfectly. The guava and cheese one was the perfect fruity and cream cheesy desert to finish off the gooey and delicious chorizo and cheese ones. Delicious.  I went back 3 days in a row to get more... and I'll be there tomorrow again for lunch.  Now its time to search yelp for a good gym...

Holy Cubano!  90 Miles may be a small restaurant, but their food packs huge flavor.   You know it's good when I am thinking about the next time I can return while writing this review. Anyways, the Cuban Sandwich is excellent.  In my opinion, they nailed the bread, which is one of the most criticized aspects of a great Cuban Sandwich.  It also had the perfect portions of meat, cheese, and pickle.  Outstanding!   Now the sandwich options come with a side of fried plantain chips, but I must recommend the Yuca Frita.  With that said, do not order the Yuca Frita if you are on a date or have plans later that day.  The wonderfully crispy yuca is covered in garlic.  It's so beautiful, but the side dish is guaranteed to create some space between you and  your neighborhood vampires or significant other. Overall, great service, great food, great times!

Ropa Vieja sandwich and dinner plates are very good! Juicy and tasty meat.  One place where they have Yucca fries and of course fried plantains. Only downside is if you go with a large group for a bday-they charge you corkage fee PLUS cake-cutting fee...we ended up paying 20% of our bill just for that. So definitely wouldn't go there for a birthday!

I've recently struck a fancy and appreciation for cuban food... and this place is fantastic. My husband and I split an empanada sampler and each ordered a different "special" of the day. It was some kind of pork dish with garlic sauce, black beans and rice. It was so flavorful. The portion was rather large which lead to indulging the next day when it tasted even better than the first time. My husband had the ox tail special.  Of note... I noticed freshly painted signage from none other than Guy Fieri hanging behind the register. The associate explained to me that he has recently visited and there would be a special about 90 miles on one of his shows (which has probably aired already).  I do wish they had more seating inside. I suppose in the mid fall to early spring this joint becomes mainly a take-out place. Regardless, a great place to dine al fresco for some fresh cuban in the spring and summer!

Pretty yummy overall, and I would say that "I'm a fan" to this place. I'm probably more like a 3.5 though. Came here with some friends for lunch on a Sunday around noon. There were not too many people around, so our orders came out quickly. The patio is great when the weather is nice.  I left my search of the perfect vegetarian-friendly sandwich to try something new. The waitress suggested one of the specials, a portobello with substitute meat crumbles ($5.95). I enjoyed it, and it was fulfilling and yummy, but I don't remember anything outstanding about the flavor. Maybe I should have tried the tofu sandwich (though I was trying to gauge how firm the tofu would actually be.) My friend ordered empanadas to see if she liked them. She tried several different flavors, including one meat, one veggie, one goat cheese + jam. I thought they weren't filled very much and the veggie one was unimpressive. The goat cheese + jam one was good though! I'm a sucker for those flavors. She ran back to the counter get a lechon (pork) sandwich and I think that was much better. Hearing about others' meat sandwiches makes me jelly to eat meat. We also shared some tostones, or flat, fried plantains with garlic. I love tostones and smothered it with the topping, though eating so much garlic turned out to be a bad choice for later in the afternoon.

I can't really say that my first few experiences here were great.  I ordered the steak sandwich and found the steak dry and flavorless.  The maduros (fried plantain) was overdone and sopped in oil.  I had just about given up.  A couple of months later, I decided to give it one last chance.  I ordered my usual... steak sandwich (sanwich de bistec) and maduros.  I don't know what they did, but it was great!!  The sandwich was juicy and flavorful.  The maduros were perfectly cooked.  Yay me!!  My son really loves their empanadas.  These come in handy when you have to eat on the go.  I hope this great streak continues.  I love the improvements and I'm finally going to have to try something else on the menu.

We went to the one in Roscoe Village - a tiny little place with minimal indoor seating and a handful of outdoor tables.  The food was so delicious - we ordered the cuban, ropa vieja, and the pork plate (sorry, the name escapes me). We also ordered the empanadas and americano coffee.  All were so delicious - no complaints on the taste of the food. The service was super friendly and eager to please. My only complaint is that they got our order wrong . We didn't say anything so I can't hold it against them, and I'm sure they would have fixed it pronto if we did.  I highly recommend this place - although with the weather changing, it may be to-go instead of dining in.

I was impressed how quickly we were seated.  It's in Roscoe Village so I thought it would be packed.   Like other cuban places, you order your food and they serve your table.  Food was pretty darn good, although I the black beans weren't quite cuban enough for me.  The white rice and chicken dish was very good. I like a Taste of Cuba a little better.  It's in Lincolnwood, but I think it's worth the drive. You may also want to try Cafe 28 on Irving and Damen.
Delicious, well priced Cuban food.. just go.
The sandwhiches are great, but if you have twenty bucks treat yourself to one of their great dinners, or add a milkshake to your meal. I never walk out here displeased in any way.

I just stopped in here today for some lunch.  Today and every time in the past, I've always been greeted with a smile and a hello when it was time to order.  I don't vary my purchases far from their Cubano sandwiches, but everything friends and I have always shared have been fantastic. There's a nice patio to sit outside and eat in.  The staff always brings your food outside when it's ready, and the location has a nice little parking lot so you can avoid parking on the street.  This place ranks right up there with the shops that sell similar food in little Cuba in Miami.  If you can't book a flight to south Florida, go here!

Wow- after the first bite, I knew I would be coming back.  I saw this featured on Diners, Drive-ins, and Dives. I was a little lost in ordering from the menu. The cashier helped me settle on a lechon (pork) sandwich with grilled onions and maduros (fried plantains). The sandwich was great, the service was friendly, and the coffee was great.

I lived in Miami for 5 years, and really didn't think cuban food like this existed in Chicago.  Some friends took me out for a celebration dinner, and they couldn't have picked a better place.  I loved it.  I had the Puerco Rostizado and it was awesome.  It's a pork dish that's roasted over night, with bacon and I have no idea what else.  If there's one thing Cuban food is known for, it's pork.   Awesome.  I loved the black beans and rice plus sweet plantains too.  Great for the price too.   I picked the dish because it was featured on "Diners Dives and Drive-Ins Chicago", but everything on the menu looks awesome.  I'm looking forward to taking my wife there soon.

Oh yeah!! Major Nommyness to be had here with the all fruit Guayaba shake, yuca garlic fries and the veggie Cuban sandwich! I was never a fan of the actual Cuban sandwich, but this veggie version knocked my pantalones off! A definite place to stay in my little black book of nomnommmmmmms!
great cubano. really a quality place, food not greasy, prepared to order. definitely worth it.
Really enjoy the lechon (pulled pork) dinner.  Wish it was a less pricey for lunch as I can't eat sandwiches because of celiac's and can't justify $14 lunches, but definitely tasty.

I brought my Havana born mother to this spot in Logan Square. It was one of the last Cuban restaurants in Chicago we needed to check off our list. She got the Lechon dinner plate and I got the croqueta sandwich, both of which were delightful. My girlfriend got the chicken dinner and it was finely seasoned. My mom was completely stoked you could order her favorite soda, Iron Beer!! 90 Miles is BYOB which also makes it a great spot however since we were seeing The Dark Knight Rises afterwards we opted against drinking. We did see a table with their very own mojitos that looked amazing; all they had to do is bring the rum and 90 Miles made the rest of the mixture.  Lastly, the outdoor seating is wonderful and we sat outside as it was a gorgeous Chicago evening.

I'll make this short and sweet. This is the best Cuban food I've had outside of Miami beach.  Eff it, it's just as good as what I've had in South beach.  The food was fantastic. I had an hour to kill up near Roscoe village, so I figured I'd try out 90 Miles since it was so highly reviewed on Yelp.  I definitely over-ordered, getting the fried plantaines and--at the advice of the yelpers--the ropa Vieja.  It was so good.  The ropa with their special hot sauce was a perfect combo.  Very flavorful meat.  I came back the next day (this should tell you something) for the cuban sandwich.  It was even better.  I love a good cuban sandwich, so I think I'm partial in that way.  Still, though, it was so good. If you like cuban food, this should be a stop in the city.  I definitely won't be forgetting about it.

By far the best Cuban food I have had!!!!!! The restaurant inside is small and the seating is diner style with stools along the wall and counter. They do however provide a small intimate patio. I love to come in here and order the Huajarito - Delicious  steak sandwich with lettuce, tomato sandwiched by two pieces of crispy, sweet and salty plantain!!!!! No bread!!!!!!!!!!! It is so juicy, flavorful and soooooooooo delicious!!!! If you are looking for something more filling like a larger meal, I recommend the Ropa Vieja, which is pulled beef. You can order it with beans and rice and they are so tasty, yes - even better than Mexican beans and rice!  If you want to taste something more eccentric try the Rabitos - Oxtail stew!!!!!!!  OMG - SO tender and the meat almost melts off the bone!!!!! This place thinks of everything when making everything tasty for the customers that even the water is tasty with courtesy lemon water at the entrance. The Cuban espresso will provide the perfect jolt especially with it's paired with their sweet Guava pastry!!!! I often come here and have been pleased every time!!!!

90 Miles is a great place to get some tasty Cuban style food. You can't go wrong with the goat cheese and chorizo empenadas, and the sandwiches are very tasty as well (I enjoy the media noche and the croquette sandwiches the most). The Ropa Vieja (sp?) was quite tender and tasty also - well worth having. Don't forget to have some tasty coffee while you are there too! The only detractor to this particular location is that it is quite small inside. If you really need more room for a group, you can always go to the other location where they have a lot of tables. However, I like the people here better ;) Well worth visiting!

Please, please visit 90 Miles Cuban Cafe. You won't regret it. For maximum pleasure do the following things: -Upon arrival, order a round of Pastelitos de Guayaba y Queso Crema (guava and cream cheese pastries) along with some Cortaditos. There are many varieties of Pastelitos, but these are filled with guava paste and a special, sweetened cream cheese mixture. They have a delicate, flaky pasty shell and are perfect for dipping into Cuban espresso--the world's finest espresso, especially when mixed with a little steamed milk. Anyway, the Pastelitos are brought in from Miami proper and they sell out very quickly, which is why you should ask for them right away. They're unmissable. Also worth noting, if you're there for the experience, the Pastelito and Cortadito combination is as classic-Cuban as it gets. -The portions here are humongous. Plan to share an entree (or two, depending on your party's size) and order a few appetizers instead of one mega entree per person. As far as selection goes, I've tried almost everything and I think that the two best entrees are the Bistec (so huge) and Ropa Vieja dishes. The Ropa Vieja, which translates into 'old clothes' is a savory, shredded beef dish cooked for hours in a tomato-garlic-saffron stew.  It's served with rice, beans and sweet plantains--a thing of beauty. -The Croquetas are also absolutely delicious. Order those. The sauce they are served with isn't a traditional accompaniment, but I love it. -Also, order the Mariquitas. The Mariquitas are shaved, fried plantain chips. They are highly munchable and extremely addictive. They come with a side of Mojo (garlic in oil, basically) which I enjoy pouring all over the Mariquitas, the rest of my food and myself.  -Lastly, we all know this place is byob and that's great, but one of these days you should order the Jupiña--a supremely awesome pineapple soda that Cuban people feed their children so that their tropical bodies grow up full of crazy. It's so good, sweet and unique. Don't miss it either.  I'm Cuban American, born and raised in Miami's Little Havana. I would know.
Sweet staff and DELICIOUS food. Best to go during nice weather so you can enjoy the patio.
I love this place.  The food is outstanding but not overly-priced.  Plus you will have fun eating here.

My first impression upon arrival was- "This is tiny... how quaint!"  Somehow though (silly me), I got confused and thought they didn't serve standard American espresso drinks. Sadly, I turned to leave this adorable little place, but the barista waved me over and asked why I was leaving. I explained with a most pathetic look on my face (I'm sure)  that I couldn't have any form of dairy anymore- not even soy. Sugar either,  and that I couldn't have any of their tasty-sounding drinks. But the barista, warm and polite, explained to me that he could absolutely make me an Americano. And boy, was that Americano good! I'm really trying to get my girlfriend to come here with me. She's not a coffee drinker, but I think the look of the place will win her over and we'll be able to make more pit stops here. Thanks, 90 Miles!

I tried the cubano the first time I came here. it was ok. I think the mustard is a bit too much for me. My 2nd time here, I tried the Ropa Vieja and I liked it much more than the Cubano. Friendly place to stop by to get a quick bite. I ordered it to go both time since the place is a bit small and it was crowded both time I was there. I keep on forgetting to come back just because I don't use that section of Clybourn Ave. Maybe once a year. Nice place. I would definitely stop to eat if I ever drive by it.

Wow. I was so happy I went here for lunch since I've been meaning to try them out for a while now.  And OMG I will definitely return! It was my first time there and they were able to suggest some of their popular dishes.  I'm not a pork person so I chose ropa vieja (pulled beef mixed w/ sauce [i forget the name of the sauce]).  Also since I have a sweet tooth, also ordered a side of maduros (fried plantains, sweetened).   The Ropa Vieja was delicious.  It was a lot of beef but it was so good i ate all of it.  Top it off w/ maduros, oh man oh man. I was so happy! O yes, I also had mango shake and I was in heaven! Will definitely return!

I love Cuban food, and this was the best I've ever had, hands down. Since this was my first time at the restaurant, I had the waitress walk me through the menu and suggest some options. I ended up getting the pulled pork dinner, my husband had the ropa vieja dinner, and we shared a chorizo & cheese empanada. Whoa. It. Was. Delicious. The pulled pork was slow cooked for hours and had a melt-in-your-mouth flavor. The ropa vieja was also very good, but I liked my dish a bit better. This place is no frills dining. The inside is very small with only counter top space indoors and there's a modest patio for outdoor seating. It looks a little like a shack from the outside, but don't be intimidated! It's some of the best food you'll have! I'll definitely be back again.

The medianoche is delicious!  So are the masas de puerco, which I think might be a special some nights...  If you're not sure, ask the staff.  They are SOOOO nice and offer up lots of great suggestions!  I usually get my food to go, but the hubby and I like to grab an empanada to eat there while we wait for our orders.  I find the goat cheese empanadas to be delicious.  Also... the coconut flan... ohmygod....

How do you say, "Damn that's a delicious sandwich," in Cubano? This little stop offers huge flavors, and authentic Cuban fare.  It is small inside, with a little counter space to enjoy your food, but there are a handful of tables on the patio.  There is also a bowl of water outside for your dog, or your buddy that forgot his wallet at home.   My favorite sandwich is the Media Noche, which is the Cubano on a delicious sweet n' savory bread.  The sandwich has cheese, pickles, mustard, ham, and a karate chop of flavor.  90 Miles Cafe also has this smokin' hot red pepper sauce that is incredible.  The sauce definitely burns your mouth, but in a good way;  Fellow spice aficionados will enjoy the heat for sure.  Look for this Cuban Cafe to be on an upcoming Diners - Drive ins - and Dives.  That spiky haired flake Guy Fieri was spotted here recently shooting an episode, enjoying his food, and looking like an idiot.

Being my first foray into Cuban food, I can say without reservation, I will be back. Inexpensive, hearty, and filling.  Three of us shared several menu items, including a traditional cuban sandwich, avocado salad (whole avocados!!), a special of the day with spanish chorizo, a ropa vieja empenada, and some sweet plantains. We sat outside on the patio despite the looming storm (we made it out just in time).  THe patio area was great, the neighborhood is fun.  We were able to walk from my bestie's new digs, so I think we'll be making 90 miles a regular spot. And props for the clever name.

Holy crap. We love 90 Miles.   The first time I tried this place I did all the specials and had a fantastic experience.  The appetizer special was a coconut shrimp with a dipping sauce. My husband and I randomly still talk about eating this dish.  "Remember that coconut shrimp at 90 miles?" "Oh man, I could have just drank that sauce." We have this conversation on a regular basis.  I also had a pork shank for the first time. Where has that been all my life? It was tender and falling off the bone. Served with spinach and sweet potatoes. Very flavorful. The calamari with marinara was tasty and I really want to try the Cubano sandwich.  I love the lounge place they have for you to wait. It's cozy and intimate. You can actually have a conversation and start your night as opposed to standing around and waiting outside.

Very tasty! I had the Cuban sandwich and took half of it home for lunch the next day. The guy behind the counter was very helpful in making suggestions if you weren't familiar with Cuban food. I've tried to go back a few times with my boyfriend but it has been packed and we were too hungry to wait. For sure going back though!

Dare I say i found a gem, hidden on the dirty Cly...yes.  Came to waste time as my cat was getting her blood work and ultrasound done...so I had an hour.  The cat's kidneys were a tad small, adrenals need some help, spleen is large, she has anemia which they still aren't sure if why...But yeah the Cuban place.  No complaints, i like the small size, kinda old school.  This is the kinda place Ricky Ricardo would take Lucy to after swinging to his the sounds of his band all night, and lil Ricky...back to food.  I drank two shakes which were great, cured my hangover...And had the lunch special.  Prices were competitive...15 dollars for me...ten's about average after taxes etc.  I would go back and back and back
According to Yelp you don't need a reservation. Apparently you do....noted, I'm now waiting a hour and a half for a table and it's only 7:40 :( not cool.

Went here today for a late lunch, and glad we got there at an odd time since I had no idea how teeny-tiny the place was. There is a small parking lot that had plenty of spots available, so that was good. Staff was super friendly and helpful as I ordered a Cuban sandwich, Ropa Vieja dinner, goat cheese empanada, mango and mamey (never heard of that, but counter girl suggested it) shakes. We were lucky enough to get two of the 10(ish) stools in there. It would kinda suck to go there and order food and not be able to sit down and eat it.  Food came out quickly. Presentation was fine, and food was excellent. I've never had a Cuban sandwich and it was yum, but I think a few more plantain chips would've been good...there were like 8 small chips on the side. Ropa Vieja was really great, served with rice, black beans, and plantains. The empanada was smallish for the price and we got beef instead of goat cheese as ordered, so bummer, but we ate anyway it and it was tasty. They aren't giving anything away here...$32 for lunch, so it was a bit pricey considering the small space. Nothing against a dive-y place, but they don't even have a bathroom. I suppose it would be nice to sit outside there, but again, there's the bathroom thing. Since the food was so great I would love to go back, but I would try the other location which looks like it has more seating...like a regular restaurant. I'm sure I will be craving that Ropa Vieja sooner than later...

i really want to like this place but after my 3rd visit i decided NOT to come back again. This place looks really cool, small and cozy, you feel you are not in Chicago! Good food choices, BYOB is a plus, outdoor sitting. 1st time I came here, the food was excellent but then I had to run in the bathroom for No 2. I have eaten to many places over my 28 years and this never happened to me before. I wasn't going to come back but the 2nd time I came here was with a group of friends that wanted to try this place. Whatever. 2nd time around, the sandwich I had was just ok, the goat cheese empanadas are the best here and the exotic drinks, the calamari was the most HORRIBLE calamari I ever tried in my life! And to top it off I paid nearly 40$ for something I didn't enjoy. Yeap, the food here is expensive! Also, this place doesn't even have a washroom for their costumers. isn't this illegal? There is no reason for me to come back here again.

My sister-in-law brought me to this unassuming Cuban restaurant, and I'm sure glad she did! The food was fresh, the hot sauce spicy, and the empanadas were out of this world.  The ropa vieja was the standout -- saucy, a little sweet, and exploding with awesome flavors.  The beef and the chorizo are certainly recommended. For desert I had the cascos de guyaba.  I guess I didn't believe the description of Guava shells with cream cheese and crackers... but that's what it was.  Tasty guava pieces surrounding a fistfull of plain-ol' cream cheese, with saltines stuck into it.  I can't say it was my favorite desert of all time, but there's something homey about it that I suppose would be compelling. All-in-all though, a great experience.  Friendly, helpful servers.  BYOB (we brought two beers and weren't charged a corkage fee), outdoors-indoors atmosphere, and awesome food.

My BF and I went here for a late lunch on Saturday.  For 2pm in the afternoon there was still quite a pretty sizable crowd there but the line moved quickly and after we placed our order we were able to find a seat outside pretty easily.  I ordered the pork sandwich and my BF ordered the beef sandwich and we decided to share a chorizo empanada.  Our sandwiches came with a drink for an extra dollar - def worth it!  I had a con leche coffee - it was so yummy and a very nice surprise since I had just expected black coffee.  I really liked my sandwich - the pork was very moist and tender and the plaintains were also a nice touch.  I could have used a little more flavor in the sandwich but I put some of the homemade hot sauce that came with our empanda and it did the trick.  The bread was nicely toasted. I also really like our chorizo empanada - it was heavily deep fried and came out nice and hot and it was cheesy and chorizo packed. Very affordable sandwich place and since its close to our apartment, I will be back for more!

We went there before a Bull's game so we were on a tight schedule.   The server was great; efficient and speedy.   He suggested good items and kept us on track.  The food was very good and reasonably priced.  It's a BYOB place so I am looking forward to going back with a bottle of libations and more time to spend.

Ordered delivery online for the first time on 3/31/12. After 1.5 hrs (the site said it'd be 1 hour) I called to check on order. Without asking for my name or address, I was told that it was on the way. After 2 hrs, I called back, and was told they'd never received the order. I did have a confirmation number, but they said that wouldn't help. Was told they'd comp "something" the next time I ordered. No thanks. Was excited to try the food, unfortunately never got it, and won't order again.

We were in the area and thought we'd stop by to pick up some food. The restaurant has its own private parking lot which helped us because the traffic during after work rush hour was crazy. The restaurant itself is super cute from the outside. The artwork is clever and fun to look at.  The inside was a lot smaller than I had expected.  It is only counter window seating and can sit about 5-6 people max.  The rest is standing room only. I placed an order of the ropa vieja dinner to go. It came with white rice, beans, maduro (ripe plantains) and super tender and wonderfully flavored shredded beef in creole sauce. I highly recommend it! One of the best ropa vieja's I've tasted (next to the one's I've had in Florida where many Cubans are).  I also got an order of the bread pudding. It came with a cream dressing on the side (which I was not a fan of) but the bread pudding was super good! Service was great and really friendly. Prices were reasonable at about $12 for the dinner. They offer the ropa vieja on a sandwich as well for about $7. So glad we were in the neighborhood to try this place!

I went here one night for a birthday party. I had just gone to siboney the week before for a first time experience with cuban food and I was sooo pleased! So I was really excited about trying this place. Unfortunately I was so dissappointed. The food was not great. We ordered empanadas that were super cold in the middle and came with no sauce to dip it in. My entree was not cooked the way I had wanted it. My bf got the cuban sandwich which was completely bland and the yuca with it also extremely cold in the middle. Our server Ryan, was absolutely fantastic and the hostess was very nice. The ambience was awesome but not enough to get me to go back for that sad food. Im really disappointed bc it looks like a cool place.
I love this place.  I work near by and food is always ready fast.  The cubano is amazing.  It is so flavorful!  Love the plantains too!

Previously I would have given this place 5 stars but I feel there are some issues with consistency with them.  The empanadas are great, full of flavor but are kinda small and expensive and they kinda skimp on the chimichurri sauce now. They used to give you a huge tub or forget it altogether! Don't waste your time on the Snickers one, you are better off waiting for summer and getting a deep fried snicker at Ribfest! We tried the Grouper soup and it was a super fishy smelling and tasting mess, most of it went into the trash.  I like their steak with Chimichurri sauce but I think it is more for the sauce than the steak! All in all, the food is good and the service is great you just will have some trial and error with some of the food.

This is what happens when you find a solid ethnic restaurant. I haven't tried everything on the menu, but I have never EVER been dissatisfied with a meal from here. Delicious delicious delicious! Hello? Maduros for breakfast!!!!

The only Cuban café I eat at because it's that good! I usually get the Cuban sandwich or the Bistec but I highly recommend the Cuban sandwich. The fries are also scrumptious! The smoothies are all good but give the mamey a try. It's a fruit that taste like a sweet potato and pumpkin (if you like those things). The price is very reasonable.

My family loves to visit this cute, Cuban café.  The actual restaurant is very small, so we always get the food to go.  The service is always efficient and accurate.  I always get the Cuban, and my family usually splits empanadas.  Everything is consistently good with a ton of flavor.

Nomma Nomma Nomma this place is delicious.  If you're craving a sandwich, avoid those regular cold cut sandwich joints and come here instead. I went here on Sunday and had a Cuban, El Bistec, beef embpanada, and tostones. The sandwiches are less than $7 but for a around a buck more you can get a pop on the side or cafe con lech. The meat, veggie, bread ratio was all good. Not too much meat or bread, all deliciousness.  Also, they come with fried plaintain chips very crispy and not v. oily.  The tostones were a good size, like the size of a coaster and not too thick. I agree with another reviewer, I think they should add more garlic sauce.  Also, I wish the steak in the bistec sandwich had a bit more flavor it was a little bland. The place is small and only has about 10 stools. Not a  real good dine in experience. All in all a solid meal and I'll definitely come back. mmmm good

90 mile cafe ME LIKIE! They have some pretty tasty sandwiches there papa rellanes are pretty good. The soup was super salty but ok HMM I dont know I'm a big lover of Hispanic non Mexican good Puerto  rican Cuban south american etc., and i have not reveiwed many of the GREAT puerto rican cuban places i have been to  because i have just started  yelping. So with that said this place is just ok. The quality is Excellent its a very small and clean place threre ropa vieja was really good there cuban sandwich was ok. My brother likes this place a lot so i have been there a couple times.Overall its good its clean and the prices are alright. A little over hyped but the food id good. HAPPY EATS PEEPS!  P.S. Cuban coffee THATS A HUGE WAKE  UP COFFEE! EYES WIDE SHUT!
I love the steak sandwich and iced cafe con leche!! Great neighborhood place that you can always count on.

What happend? How did I get burned?  I had the highest expectations for 90 miles. All my fellow yelpers had given this place head over heals reviews.  The coffee was awesome. But the sandwich was nothing to rave about. I didnt think the flavor or assembly was mind blowing in any way. Their prices are generous, since they do deliver a nice looking and great smelling sandwich. Plus a lot of places try to take you for a ride over anything they can.  I need to give 90 miles another go, because everytime I pass the place I yell at them in my car. I know, i'm a child...

Went here for lunch on a Monday.  The decor is great (lively outside, cozy inside).  The service is amazing for what is a pretty small establishment (there are probably only a dozen or so seats inside, with more seating outside in the summer).  The sandwiches tasted great (and had fresh ingredients).  I'm impressed!

I love Cuban food but had yet to try 90 miles. It isn't too far from my office so I stopped in last week for a late, dine-in lunch. I had the bistec sandwich, my husband had the media noche and we split the croquettes and a pastillita (guava & cheese). Total was $22. The croquettes were good. They only had one version, which seemed to be ham. I had no complaints about the media noche, and the only thing that could have improved the Bistec would be more chimichurri but that is like liquid, green, crack to me. The pastillita was good, but I would have preferred a little more filling. Don't take me being nit-picky wrong....this place is great.  The staff was really awesome: patient, courteous and even offered up some recommendations.  I will most definitely be back (and will try the Lechon likely- pork and sweet plantains on a sandwich.....yes!)
The best Cuban food north of Miami!

People are going to hate me for this, and I kinda hate myself for this, too.....but 90 Miles Cuban Cafe doesn't live up to the hype for me. Granted I've only tried a few things so I'm definitely willing to come back and give it another try. Media Noche and Cubano - the meat is soo skimpy and thin in these sandwiches! Also not particularly flavorful..... Tostones were good but they needed more garlic sauce! I always have fond memories of some of my fav cuban places in NYC where they give you a full jar of sauce on the table - I needed more of that! Will come back and try some of the other platters to see if it will change my feelings.

This place is the perfect take out place for everyone.  I highly recommend ordering off of the specials menu.  The regular menu is mostly sandwiches, which are great with classics Cubano sandwich, but he specials are the best.  If you like the Cubano sandwich try the Media Noche, same sandwich but on sweet bread...my favorite way to eat it. They offer some really interesting vegetarian items like a portabello mushroom stuffed with soy meat, cheese and spices. The grouper soup is a must have as well, although they usually serve it on the weekends only.   It's getting cold now, but my favorite thing to do is order something to drink and sit on their patio.  The smoothies are awesome!  They have a lot of different fruits, I like mixing passion fruit and mango together.  The best thing you can get for breakfast is a simple cafe col lecher and a guava pastry...yum.  The pastries are flaky and gooey at the same time.

Um, I'm kind of in love with this hole in the wall place. The food is consistently fabulous. The tofu sandwich will knock any meat-a-tarian's socks off. The crispy fried plantains are sinfully good as well. My other half loves the cuban sandwiches and the rice and beans. The people are always friendly in this tiny place. The cuban music blares through the speakers and you really might just feel like you're in another world while eating there. They also do lots of takeout and delivery, if it's too crowded for your taste!
Awesome bistec sandwiches!!! small little shack that serves great FRESH foods.  Love the fresh ingredients they use.   My new fav!!  MUST GO

I had a cuban sandwich.  It was very good.  It wasn't as good as the one I used to have in Tampa, but that is a high standard.  Place is a little place and is staff were very nice.  Bread was good(very important).  Will try more things in other visits for sure.

I am in love with this place! After reading reviews on Yelp I couldn't help by drag my boyfriend along to try it out. I'm from South Florida, so I know good Cuban food when I taste it. I had my doubts about great Cuban food in Chicago but this place completely changed my mind. Of course I wanted to try everything so here is my take on this true neighborhood gem. My boyfriend and I started with beef empanadas. Can you say amazing? It was the best empanada I've ever had. It also comes with this delectable green dipping sauce. I order the Bistec meal which comes with rice, beans, and fried plantains. The skirt steak was wonderful and the grilled onions only added to the flavor. The beans were magnificent and the rice was cooked just right. The fried plantains were out of this world! I love plantains and I thought for sure that no one could do them as well as my beautiful Miami. I have never been happier to be proved wrong. My boyfriend ordered the Pollo sandwich which came with plantains chips. He also order papas fritas which were out of this world as well. The chicken was juicy and full of flavor. I couldn't believe how amazing this little hole in the wall was! I will be back for sure, to try the Pan Cubano.  I cannot wait to return!

We were on our way to get some Mediterranean food when this little place caught our eye.  We quickly jerked into the parking lot to give it a try and we are so glad we did.  This little Cuban shack serves up large portions of fabulousness.  The flash fried pork and plantains were crazy great.  Even better was a large basket of fried yucca - oh yeah!!!! Don't expect table serve, let alone a table.  This tiny joint is decorated cutely and has the nicest counter girl you could ever ask for.

Let me preface by saying I had a short stint in NJ. The prices for the quality and quantity of food out there are jawdropping. The food here is pretty darn good tood, the only thing that is lacking is service. Yes, i know this is pretty much it when it comes down to Cuban food. That doesn't mean you have keep your nose so darn high. First time I stopped in I shook it off as the person behind the counter is having a bad day. Second time around got the same snippity attitude. If it wasn't because food is pretty good and I enjoy having different latin flavors besides mexican food I probably wouldn't be so kind.

One word: Tostones. If you don't know what they are then you won't even know when they are done right. Had daily special: Bistec with Tostones and a salad. The salad was blah but as expected. The steak was really good, the cut of meat was bad but however they cooked it made it better. Wish I would have had it in a sandwich instead of covered in grilled onions but now I know better.... Wanted an order of Tostones to go....yes, they are that good.

This place is BYOB, so bring some spiced rum and go nuts. My first cuban restaurant in Chicago turned out to be a smashing idea (thanks, Interwebs!). The food is awesome, especially compared to what we get in Milwaukee! One word of warning: all the portions are crazy big. I was hungry, got a bistec, and could not finish more than half of it.  The bistec (flash fried, stuffed with ham and cheese) came with a side of bread with garlic butter. The food was delicious and the music made the night. Then we went to go see Beirut at the Congress, making it a very worthwhile trip to the Windy City.
This place is awesome. The food is fantastic and way under priced. Everything from the nightly specials to the Cuban burger is top notch.  The ambiance is awesome, and their flan is always great.

I really wish I lived closer to 90 Miles. I think I would be tempted to eat there daily. The Media Noche sandwich is a nice change of pace from a basic Cuban sandwich, and I thought it was damn good. The plantain chips add a nice snack to any sandwich. I loved the small atmosphere of the place, and I really can't wait to come back and dig deeper into their menu.

This place is AWESOME. I've only been here once but I'm already a huge fan and can't wait to come back. The Bistec steak sandwich was absolutely delicious--the shoestring potatoes were an awesomely unique touch and the chimichurri sauce was amazing. A friend and I split the fried plantain appetizers and I'm not sure what they put on top--some sort of garlic, olive oil concoction--but it was so good. A little redundant though, since the sandwiches come with a side of plantain chips as well. But nevertheless, this place is definitely one worth trying.
Amazing Cuban food.  Amazing Cuban coffee.  Kind of small so I generally take everything to go. Thanks

Pretty good -- but not "dios mio!" -- Cubano sandwiches. Haven't found one in Chicago yet that tops the ones I could get in NJ. But combine a decent Cubano with good prices and great, friendly service, and that's why I dig making the occasional visit to 90 Miles. The inside seating is counter/stools only, and they have a nice outside patio with many tables. Can't speak to the other menu items other than the empanadas, which were really good (don't think I've ever had a bad empanada, but that's besides the point...). But the empanadas and the Cubanos were both good enough that I'll be making more visits and exploring more of the menu. I'd recommend the place.

Food pretty good, Although dont try and tell the Hipster behind the counter what you want in spanish he or she will jus go "uhh you want the wha???" and I have to refrain from slappin the glasses without lenses off his head and say once again... ahem.. "MEDIA NOCHE!!!!" kinda small too, over all good for a quick bite

I'm 20 miles away from this place and will be coming back all the time.  Hell, I'll drive 90 miles just to score some of this stuff.  They make the BEST cuban food I've ever had.  Can I hire you guys to cook at my place?  That would make my life a whole lot easier...And I'd save on gas.. just sayin.. but ill be back, and been spreading the word of this cuban-awesomeness cheers

My wife and I had some errands to run on the north side of the city of Chicago today.  So where should we go for lunch??  We decide on 90 Miles Cuban Cafe on 3101 North Clybourn.  Now we have never been to this tiny little restaurant right on the corner.  But we have heard many good things.  Maria and I decide to order food to eat at the restaurant and food to take home for later with the kids. We ordered 2 Cubano sandwiches (ham, roast pork, swiss cheese, pickles & mustard on French bread) at $6.95 each.  The Cubano was a good average sandwich.  Nothing truly to write home about.  Three Bistec sandwiches (steak, romaine lettuce, tomato, grilled onions, shoestring potatoes & chimichurri sauce) at $6.95 each.  The steak was seasoned very well.  Of course we did think it was weird to have shoestring (just like from a Jays can) potatoes on the sandwich!  Three orders of Ropa Vieja, my true Cuban favorite sandwich (shredded beef, peppers & onions long-cooked in Creole sauce) for $6.95 each.  This was a good sandwich, Maria thought a bit heavy on the peppers though.  One order of Tostones (green plantains) at 5 for $3.50 each.  And we will say they definitely needed salt.  Which should have been sprinkled on as they came out of the cooker and were nice and fresh and hot.  We also thought this for the Tostones and the Mariquitas we received too.  No salt which hurt the true taste and flavor of the items.  Three orders of the Croquetas (mix of ham and chicken) at 4 for $4.50 each.  These were really GOOD!  Two Beef Empanadas and two Ropa Vieja Empanadas at $2.50 each.  Another very good item, a bit greasy though.  Two Pastelito (Guava and cheese) and One Pastelito (Carne) for $1.95 each.  Also two bread Puddings at $2.50 each.  Finally one Coke for a dollar and one Mango Tropical Shake for $3.50 each. Overall with a total bill of roughly $108 dollars.  We thought the food was good.  The service was friendly.  Have we had better, yes I think Senor Pan was MUCH BETTER!  And much cheaper too.  And also being a Cuban family, it was close to home made food but still not quite there yet.  Sorry about that 90 Miles, you were nice to try though.

....so, we tried it.  adorable space.  spiffy menu.  kinda expensive for the neighborhood & the food they serve, but it's all good.   a little bit greasy on the papas fritas, and a wee bit light on the veggies in the veggie sandwich, but hey, i'm not cuban, maybe that's how it's done.   only bummer was the dude behind the cash register was clearly not cuban.

You want to know the real reason Ricky Ricardo was always agitated and grumpy on I Love Lucy? No, it wasn't the crazy schemes his wife was always getting into and having them backfire. It was the lack of good quality Cuban food. I know, I've lived in New York. They have everything under the sun except good Mexican and Cuban food (at least that I was able to find). Had Ricky lived near this gem, he would have taken Lucy's harebrained ideas in stride. The ropa vieja sandwich was really, really delicious and came with some plantain chips on the side. You can order and eat at the counter that lines the back walls, or have a seat outside. This spot is both intimate and laid back. So, I think it does well to represent the style of many of our neighbors to the south. We are over 900 miles away from Miami, where the best Cuban food in the U.S. is found, but 90 Miles does a great job of holding up this cuisine in this part of the country. I will definitely be back!

Came here for lunch with the bestie. I'll probably give them 3.5 stars. It was a bit chilly that day so we opted to sit inside. Place is small, but cute and clean. For me I got the Bistec and a coke - The steak was cooked very nicely. Sandwich was a good size. Only thing was it had a pretty overpowering onion taste to it. Fried plantains were good. My friend opted for the Frita Cubana and Malta - She tried the Malta and didn't like it. She said it tasted like a very strong Sugar Cane drink. She was going to go up and buy a coke, but the guy offered her a pineapple soda in replacement. How cool. She said the sauce on her burger reminded her of a sloppy joe.  I would like to come back to try some other items. The guy was nice and he even came by to ask my friend if the drink was ok.  I did ask if they had a restroom and he said no. He said I could wash my hand in this little sink they had in the corner behind the register.
Delicious Cubana but when people ask for "no pickles", they really mean it.

We have only had Cuban food a couple times but we loved this place. You might need help with the menu (we did) and it was a month or so back so I don't remember what we had but they were on the specials menu. Very tasty and different. The price is right. The outdoor eating area is great, as well as the BYOB aspect. Very friendly and helpful staff. There is no restroom for guests (so have your kid go before you leave home). There is a small parking lot.

Highly recommended. Great food with interesting spices, friendly staff, cute outdoor seating with uplifting Cuban music and reasonable prices. Plus, free parking. I felt like I was on vacation. I had the ropa vieja and yuca fries-excellent! My husband had the avocado salad and some plantains-also very good. Check it out!

Stumbled across this place on a rainy Sunday.   Was on my way to Irazu Costa Rican restaurant, but realized it was closed Sundays.  Big BOO!  Anyways, en route to Irazu 90 Miles Cuban Cafe caught my attention because of the amazingly arranged/large outdoor seating patio.  As soon as I found out Irazu was closed I turned the car around and headed to "that Cuban place with the cute outdoor seating".    Overall:  A-OK.    Food was delicious.  Meal prices were a little too high for my liking...especially since the original plan was to head to the more affordable Irazu but the food was good enough to satisfy my taste for a Latin steak sandwich and rice and beans.  An appetizer and a meal made me full --- and I had enough leftover from my meal to take home. Also tried a Guanabana Tropical shake that was milky and tasty bursts of fruits. The atmosphere was even better than the food!  Loved how it was decorated inside and out -- which was my main attraction to it in the first place.   I felt like I was taking a mini-vacay away from Chicago to a more tropical locale. I'd come back here again when I'm looking to splurge more than my usual $10 for dinner on a Sunday night and with a bigger group than 2.  Btw, it's BYOB -- if you want.

I've never had Cuban food, really, except for a cubano sandwich, but then I found myself here last night ... being dead tired at that.  After trying some of 90 miles fair, I perked right up.  AWESOME.  We got some appetizer with chorizo that was to die for, and then I got the bistec plate ... amazing.  Great stuff.

Food is good but the prices are outragous i can go elsewhere and get same food half the price empanadas are good also but once again price wow ..i know ur catering to the yups in roscoe but damn there gettn robbed  ...

I usually research restaurants before trying them, but 90 mile cafe was one that I just happened to walk into...What a delight! Their Cuban Steak Sandwich is as good as it gets. Great Place to stop in and have a quick Lunch.

As promised, I went back to 90 Miles Cafe. I just can't pass up on a good Cuban sandwich or their guava pastelitos. Just as the owner said I must have been there on a day things were somewhat off. Not this time around.  The food was delicious. I even brought a new friend with me and he said the food was "scrumptious". I'll be coming back!

I love this place, and I can't wait to go back and take more people. Pros - Great food.  Everything tastes homemade like someone's Momma made it.  Portions are also big, but not ridiculous. - BYOB and theres no corkage fee.  I saw people bringing in large containers of margaritas for large groups. - The food has a great price point.  We had empanadas, skirt steak, shrimp, and some slow cooked chicken dish.  Everything was great, and the bill was under 100. - They have a great sangria.  All you need is the red wine. - Fun atmosphere, great outside seating.  I felt like I was on vacation. Cons The only negative thing is that the bathroom is small, and there's only 1...and it's in the middle of the kitchen.  I kept drinking to much wine, and it was a pain to have to go to the bathroom.  Oh well....

After taking in a matinee show, we headed to 90 Miles Cuban Cafe to sit in the sun (well, the shade but outside nonetheless) and order some good Cuban sandwiches. I ordered the veggie sandwich and a guava/cheese empanada.  I thought both were excellent.  The sandwich was busting full of yummy veggies.  I could only eat one half and even that was a struggle.  I highly recommend that those with smaller tummies, try to find someone to split an order.  I also splurged with the guava/cheese empanada, which was equally as awesome.  Each bite had the right combination of flavor and texture.  I was glad to have something with a different flavor profile to accompany the veggie sandwich.
