The service was great.  I went to grab a water bottle from the cooler but was quickly informed by the staff that they had tap water readily available outside.  Unfortunately they were out of ice and in the hot sun, the water turned quickly warm.   The outdoor seating isn't anything spectacular but was sort of perfect at the same time.  One of the best parts about it was that it was off to the side, not really near the entrance.  This eliminated patrons from walking through to place their orders and left those of us seated peacefully off to the side.  It's the little things, ya know.

"Ooh, calamari for only five dollars?  Score!" No.  No no no.  A thousand times no.  Clearly I should have known better.   What was described on the menu board as "big pieces of calamari with a zesty tomato sauce" was in fact a handful of tiny, limp, rubbery grey rings the size of my pinky finger, hidden inside a giant cup of tomato sauce.  Now, it didn't actually taste terrible, but this was nowhere near a quality calamari dish (trust me, I'm a connoisseur).  It was like a game of Bobbing for Squid Rings or the deep-sea trawling industry in miniature--dip in the fork, feel around for anything more solid than a tomato chunk, pull up the fork, and hope to come up with something like a calamari ring.  I think that I got around ten or twelve of them in thirty or forty dives. So stick with the sandwiches, which are still great, and for heaven's sake eschew the calamari and the empanadas. I am inclined to drop them to three stars for the awful veggie empanada and the calamari misadventure, AND because they were out of ice (yes, ice!) and could not make any shakes.  But those two sandwiches (lechon and veggie) were damn good, and the service is still top-notch.  So I'm officially registering this one as 3.5 stars.

Not so bad. I think my reason for three stars is that the Guijarito sandwich was not as good as the Jibarito from Papa's Cache Sabroso in Humboldt Park. I also was disappointed they didn't have a lot of the dessert empanadas. The actual meat empanadas are very tasty and the location is pretty good, right on Clybourn in Roscoe Village. I think it's primarily a take-out place considering only in the summer-time they have a good portion of seating availability. I think there are better Cuban options nationally, and perhaps even in Chicago but they are doing a good job and I salute their efforts.

Hands down, the best Cuban food you will find in Chicago.  I'm a vegetarian, and most people think of the ham and cheese Cuban sandwich when they think of Cuban food--You have to know there's so much more! While, I've been assured (from my carnivore friends) that the meat options are tasty, there are plenty of veggie things to be had.  All of the food is made to order.  I love the fried plantains and the Timba sandwich is my staple. If you're a smoothie fan, the guanabana is amazing! (As is the singing that ensues after your order.)  The only drawback is that this location is very small. If you have a large group, go to the one on Armitage--much more seating there. Clybourn has an outdoor patio in the summer but you're left with much less options in the winter. I love the old Cuban news papers that are pasted on the walls, as well as the Cuban music that often makes me wiggle a little dance in my seat as I eat.  This place truly makes my tummy happy! :)

Not bad. The prices are competetive. The food is tasty. The service is fast.  They have plantains which are deep fried to perfection. The portions are formidable and force you to dig deep into your fat american waistband.  I almost gave it five stars immediately when I pulled up and noticed they embrace the cuban notion of extreme poverty and their country's deep love of harboring dangerous stray dogs.
The food is excellent, the best Cuban food I have had in Chicago. The Roscoe Village location doesn't have a restroom for customers.  I find that strange, so just be warned.

Food: Typically delicious but has lost it's flare as it's grown up! Would highly recommend other establishments for much more authentic sit down experience.  If you're looking for a quick fix of Cuban food and a great open space outside, be ready for a wait on space and time. The staff is very courteous, clean presentation. Would go back on that weekday when you're in the mood for a nice stroll to lighten the burden of the heavy calorie intake!

Boyfriend and I went here for dinner on a weeknight and had a fantastic experience. We wanted something a little more special than pub grub but didn't want to spend more than $40 for the two of us. This place hit that on the mark. In fact, it came in under $40. Our total bill was just $36 with tip. We arrived on bikes and with lots of gear, so requested to be seated outside, along the railing so we could chain up next to the table and not get all our stuff in anyone's way. Hardly an unreasonable request as most of the tables out front appeared to be vacant and it was still a bit early but it seemed to have ruffled the hostess.. Alas, five minutes later, we had just what we wanted -- a table for two, outdoors, with space for bikes and all our stuff. Our server Margherita was incredibly friendly and helpful. We asked her recommendations on entrees, which were excellently delivered. I had the chicken, he had the steak. Both were fantastic. Wish we'd listened to her on the appetizers, though. We went on a recommendation from boyfriend's friend who had been there before. Tostones. The garlic 'sauce' wasn't really a sauce so much as flecks of sauteed garlic that was so skimpily scattered over the plantains, there was just too little flavour going on. The rice pudding? Delicious!!! We brought a bottle of wine. Didn't have to pay a corkage fee. And we were clued on a helpful little tidbit.. they have blenders and aren't opposed to mixing your drinks should you decide to rock up with the fixins for margaritas, mojitos, etc. Overall, everything was great. We'll definitely be back and happily recommending them to friends. Probably won't be order the tostones, though.

I went with my girlfriend a couple of weeks ago and had a really nice time. We had a chance to sit on the front patio, the entire place looks like a lot of fun so we would have been happy anywhere.  They BYOB was complimented with pitches of sangria mix, $12 I think. Our waiter was extremely helpful with our decisions on our dishes. He was a lot of fun despite the fact that it was fairly busy in his section. The food was amazing, fried pork chops and a slow cooked pork dish. We had the crouquetes as an appetizer also and they were great. The price is spot on for a higher class BYOB spot and the location is ideal for anyone on the blue line or Western/Armitage bus.

Food - amazing Service - We ordered at the counter and they were a big help with our clumsy Spanish.  Decor - This place is small and if it weren't for the outdoor seating, we would have been eating at the counter along the wall as it's the only indoor option. Not great when you're meeting friends.  Again - food AMAZING!

We have been going here since they opened on Clybourn. The food has been pretty good, the price is right and the location is convenient.  This evening I ordered via their website and when I showed up to pick-up our dinner they had no record of the order...until they looked at the printer under the cash register. Upon finding the missing order they proclaimed that the their website 'sucks' and I should phone my order and never use the online system and besides they were out of the grouper soup and did not have the chicken tamal that was on our printed order. Basically I was being told that their service failure was my fault for ordering online and ordering two items they were out of...very nice...wtf?  They are always out of the grouper soup and should take it off of the menu. The two sides of black beans we received were 85% juice and they also left out the extra side of rice that we ordered.  Very disappointed with the service and the quality of food.

Meh.   Based on all the other reviews, I feel like we were eating at an entirely different place.  First off, dinner for two at a one $ place should not have been $45. They were out of the first couple dishes I wanted. NBD, it was around 8pm on a Friday.  I went for a pork option with dirty rice and beans.  The meat was decent, but dripping with grease/oil.  Beans and rice were fine, nothing spectacular. The goat cheese empanadas had a really good flavor, but there was very little cheese inside.  I guess I just expected it to be way better based on all the reviews.....

I watched you at MU, beating Kentucky, in the Final 4 vs. Kansas, watched as you became a world beater in Miami, wishing you were a Bull, rooting FOR you in '06 vs Dallas, and, until this year, still proud to state all of the above again and again, to anyone who would listen.  In the span of a short NBA season, you have become a whiner, an instigator, a primadonna, and co-conspirator of a group of individuals playing a team sport (no, isolations and a pass don't make a team).  Woe is me...the Heat are losing and "this is what the world wants".  Coughing and teasing Dirk on camera when the series is far from over.  You let LeMoron get to you and brought you down.  You won't care at all about a diatrabe like this from one of your previously biggest fans, and even 12 months ago, I think you would at least think about it.   On to 90 Miles...I'm a loyal fan and will be for a long time (unless they make any Decisions soon...staff:  don't take your talents to Armitage).  Yes the coffee is great, the lechon rocks, maduros, steak, etc; it's been said time and time again.  The staff, however, makes this place.  In the busiest times, you are human like the rest of us reviewers, but you are quick to remedy.  In normal times, the staff is quick for a chat and a smile.  In addition, the cooks in the back at Clybourn serve big portions and prove time and time again they are better than their counterparts on Armitage.  So here is to you, 90 Miles Clybourn.  Keep doing what you do. And to the DB with the Miami hat:  even your questionable loyalty to a "team" only Miami can root for, cannot hide the fact that you are as considerate and cool as the rest of the staff there.

I've only had one thing here and so that's all I can comment on.  It was the omelet sandwich and it was delicious.  Mmmmmm.  It had eggs, ham, swiss cheese and I don't know, just goodness.  It was easy to eat, which is usually hard to say for an sandwich with egg in it.   It's a very little restaurant with tasty food with big flabors.  I can't wait to go again and try something else.

I have always enjoyed having a sandwich here for lunch, until today.  The food was decent as usual, this skinny DB (not too mention he was sporting a heat cap) who took my order, actually made feel belittled , I officially will never go back, who needs that shit!!!
Great place! Excellent Guava with cheese empanadas (turn overs). Mamey milkshake sooo gooood!! Highly recommended =D

It seems like a nice place but they ran out of food (steak & chicken). My suggestion get there before 8pm on a nice summer day. The people there are very nice and the outside seat area is cool but as a restaraunt you really cant run out of food. I am going to try this place again just for the benefit of the doubt. Right now my rating stands at a 2.

I just can't rate less than 5 stars! We were in town for our nephew's wedding, so it was a very brief visit to Chicago.  Dangit!   My Hussie just had to yelp and find such a cool Cuban cafe...and we only got to visit this cafe once.   It was lunch time and we enjoyed this meal with our newly wedded nephew and his lovely bride.  And he treated us...awwwww, extra cool. Empanada - ordered two types - 1. beef  2. goatcheese.  Mmm.  the outer skin had a nice crunch to it.  It reminds me of a perfect McDonald's fried apple pie (yes the fried pies are the bomb). Maduros - ...mmmm, that tender sweet plantains is delicious.   Avocado salad - romaine lettuce, tomatoes, red onion and a whole lotta avocado.  Best avocado I've ever had, I must say.  And seasoned with olive oil, S & P.  That's it. So simple, yet so satisfying. Cubano Sandwich - Ham, roast pork, Swiss cheese, pickles and mustard on French bread.  Pressed and toasted to perfection.   A Cuban staple you can't go without. Materva Yerba Mate Soda - when you want a quick pick-me-up.  You got some serious caffeine, sugars, and corn syrup in a can of these!  Wanted so badly to come back for dinner here, but had another engagement to attend.  Oh well, we know where to go next time we're in Chicago. Until then...Buen provecho!
Hands down the best Cuban steak sandwich in the city!! The most hospitable staff. Great location , near Costco..and if you have ever been to Clybourn Costco on a weekend- you deserve this treat!!!

I stopped here for lunch after taking a half day from work.. I ordered the Ropa Vieja.. It was pretty good, nothing off the charts.. I'd definitely go back to try something else.. funny story - I kept staring at the cashier because he looked so familiar and couldnt figure out where i have seen him before.. I'm sure he thinks im a crazy person

Great everything, down to their chicken soup (with a twist= lime!).  The only, only thing that put a slight damper on our meal was that we ordered salad with grilled veggies, not really looking at the price, and we ended up paying $13 for some romaine leaves in olive oil + salt with some red onions + bell peppers! That's just mad... minus 1 star.  On a brighter note, BYOB w/o corkage fee is pretty sweet- you can even bring your own wine to mix in with their house made sangria mix!
I love the sandwiches here! Great platinos too. Make sure to order a guava and cream cheese pastry for dessert!

4 1/2 stars.. I LOOOOOOVE this place!! I discovered it less than 2 years ago and I have been there many times since then..  The food is delicious. I have tried most of their entrees, and many of the appetizers.. and I like most of them.. with  my favorite being the churrasco. the only reason I didn't give them a 5 star, is because they tend to over cook the meat (even when I ask them not too) , that why I don't order the bistek there anymore.. its always over cooked for me..  The servers (and the owner -who's always present-) are awesome.. they know the food, they are very friendly and attentive but not overbearing..great service and feel.. The patio in the summer is very very nice, one of my favorites in the city..and it's a perfect place for large groups.. Oh , I forgot to mention that it's BYOB, and they also have Mojito and sangria mixers for $10 0r $15...

I recently excercised my right of freedom of speech, and wrote a review about my experience at this restaurant.  A few days post my review I come to find an email in my personal inbox from the owner himself. Apparently he was not satisfied with my review, and felt it necessary to send me a very rude message. i stand by my review, and if the owner is not happy, i suggest YOU remove your business from Yelp. I expect to not see another message from you in my inbox.
Loved it.  Had the day's special.  Wife had the cuban sandwhich.  And we grabbed some empanadas on top of it.  All of it good.
I would eat at 90 Miles everyday if my budget and waistline would allow it.  This food never disappoints my husband and me.  This restaurant and the sister one in Logan Square are both amazing!

Yum, yum, yum, yum, yum. 90 Miles CC is delicious it's hard to define what I like best. I stick with the signature dishes, b/c obviously they do them best.  This location is so small, but they have a great patio. Can't wait to go back

Clyborn (Roscoe Village) Pros: Food, Coffee, Atmosphere, Price, Parking Cons: Limited in Seating (Only in Winter), Area, Service (Sometimes) PROS: I was one of the first customers when "90 Miles" opened.   To say the least, I was very happy with everything they had to offer.  All of the food was fresh and really good.   Over the past year or so, the Clyborn restaurant has dipped in service, but not by much.  From time to time, they will get the order wrong but will turn around to make it right.  Sometimes by offering a free cup of coffee. This is great, considering most places would not even bother to admit they were wrong to begin with. The coffee is great, it's made really well.  It is one of my favorite brands since I grew up in a household that served Cafe Bustelo and a great alternative to Intellgentsia and Metropolis coffee that is usually offered around the Chicagoland area. The food is always amazing for me.  Any sandwich that I have ordered over the years has always been juicy, tasty and among other great words that I can not think of right now.  The price are reasonable and you do get a lot for what you pay for.  I do tend to worry about simple things costing a bit much like the Grill Cheese Sandwich ($6.50).  For as simple a sandwich can be to be close to something that has meat.  This is a bit much, but then again, if I went there for a grill cheese sandwich then I have to worry about why I am ordering it.    They also have a great (small) outside patio and parking. CONS: The bad is (and this is not much for me) during the winter month, since the place is so small, when 90 miles can be packed there is not much room to sit.  So basically for me, the winter month are mainly for pick-up and go.  This can go either way for each individual to what kind of experience they are really looking for. At this moment, the area is somewhat shady.  Most times, I have never had any issues, but I know in the past there has been numerous incidents that happen.  This is not because of 90 Miles itself, but for where it is by.  At the same token, this is just the start of a neighborhood that is up and coming.  Granted Roscoe Village is great at certain points and areas, when you head more west, its ... eh. Service sometimes can be somewhat eh too, just because they past few times I have gone they have gotten my order wrong.  I don't know if because if the person behind the counter is new or not.   The last time I ordered (about a week ago) I had ordered 4 sandwiches and received 2 sandwiches and plantains.  Granted I love my plantains, but not what I ordered... The excuse the gentleman gave me is that I ordered it wrong.  REALLY?  you are going to tell me what I wanted & ordered and debated with me what you gave to me.  I do not think so..... But issues like this are so sporadic that i just brushed it off and went on with my own business.  It is not worth dealing with idiotic nonsense like that. All in all, the place offers great food and service....

This is my FIRST review of a restaurant in Chicago as an incoming resident! WOOT! But yes, this is one of the first places I ended up yelping and trying out... and BOY, was I glad I did! Lucky for me, I had the privilege of having a friend with me, so we exchanged sandwich halves... a little bit of cubano and bistec on perfectly-toasted bread, sided with banana chips and my.. each was a taste of cuba, i swear. haven't been to cuba, but eating those delectable sandwiches in the small, cozy, cuban-culture-plastered-walls shack made the experience whole and REAL. i will definitely be back to try out some of the other sandwiches!

I pass 90 Miles Cuban Café all the time when I take my dogs to the vet and when I venture out to Costco. 90 Miles is located on Clybourn where there is pretty much nothing but residential. They have a small parking lot but there is ample parking on Clybourn. My husband went here for lunch the other day and he took me for lunch the next day. I never had Cuban sandwiches before so I was willing to try it out.  The restaurant is tiny. There are 3 small tables around the wall with stools. The walls are covered in comics and articles about 90 Miles. I love the exterior of the restaurant. There is a picture of a dog peeing and they even painted yellow on the cement. I thought it was a kitchy touch! We got there on a Saturday afternoon at noon and we got one of the last seats. They have outdoor seating but it wasn't set up since it was cool outside. We both had the Cubano sandwich and we shared some fries. It was pretty amazing and I can say I love Cuban sandwiches! Not the healthiest option but it is good for a treat once in a while. I will be back once the weather is nicer to enjoy the outdoor seating!

This is a great little dainty place. Just bar stool dining but the best. Thing to go for is the cuban sandwiches. Food is good. They have daily specials plasters on a chalk board. Coffee is thing to get here. While standing here for my take out, the place was full only after 6 mins waiting. I would recommend the specials. I just wish they didnt close so early.

90 Miles has amazing Cuban food, and that is coming from a girl from Miami with a Cuban husband.  Some of the things we have eaten and loved are the avocado salad, Croqueta Preparada sandwich, pastelitos and my favorite: Ropa Vieja.  They also have great breakfast items including delicious guava pastelitos and "coladas" which my husband loves.  Their new online ordering system is really user friendly, and I will be ordering delivery soon as I noticed there are some new vegetarian options which I'm sure will be really great.

Comforting, tasty, if simple food on the table (which seems right). Tried everything from the lamb roast special of the day to chicken soup to a simple plate of dressed avocado. My personal favorite was the quince empanada. A darling waitress. Intriguing if lively decor that did well to convince that we were not in Illinois in January.
The food here is pretty good, BYOB and friendly staff. It can get a little too loud, though, but the food is so good that you get used to that.

I ordered delivery and normally it would take an hour to get my food but they are quick and very accurate. I ordered a cuban sandwich and two empanadas and they were amazing. The sandwich was full of flavor with a yummy crunchy but soft bread. The empanadas were crisp and a guilty pleasure. If its your first time going i recommend the cuban sandwich and get an empanada the chorizo. You wont regret it.
On an absolute miserably rainy, gray Chicago day--what a find. Fun and quirky, full meals with a rare smile and Cuban black beans. Hope they come to the South Loop.

I could not believe I had never been here!  Such great food, fun atmosphere, awesome service.  I went on a Friday with a large-ish group.  We brought a bottle of rum and they gave us some mojito mix and let us sit at a table while we waited for our real table (a pretty short wait considering our group size and how busy they were).  The wait staff was totally sweet and gave good recommendations.  Everyone was happy with what they got - I got the steak cuban sandwich that is served between plantains rather than bread- YUM.  I would also recommend the plantain-shrimp cup things that come as an appetizer.   I cannot wait to go to this authentic, lively, quality restaurant again!

My husband and I went to 90 Miles Cuban Cafe for a late lunch today. We shared a fish soup, the Cuban sandwich, the Lechon sandwich and a side order of fried plantains. I"m not a big fan of fish soup but the one I had today was really delicious. I really liked the Cuban sandwich, and my husband loved the Lechon (very big with lots of pulled pork). The plantains were yummy, too. We topped it off with Cuban coffee and one empanada filled with cheese and guava. The service was very friendly and helpful. Couldn't get any better!

This is a good place for a variety of Cuban sandwiches. In addition, the Tostones were almost as big as a DVD and very tasty! The only downside is the limited seating. If you want a table, go on a warm day and sit outside.

One day, two Irish (one mostly and still in celebratory gear, the other only part) rebels made like Che (he of the part Irish rebel blood - not a fan) and headed for Cuba, er, 90 Miles Cuban Cafe.   I'd read about 90 Miles on Yelp some time ago and had had it bookmarked for some time to try based on the reviews.  It is a bit out of the way for me, so I'd never quite gotten up to it until I started driving aimlessly once again parade day plus one and it suddenly popped into my head.   90 Miles is an island oasis on North Clybourn.  From the outside, it looks like nothing more than driftwood - it's basically a shack.  Walk inside, and you still feel like you're in a shack because it's rather cozy.  The newspaper clippings on the wall will take you back to pre-revolutionary times as you await your meal.  Cuba is a party island. We ordered a Cubana and a Pollo with a side of fried plantains.  Whoa.  Drugs.  Talk about an instant double shot of love to send you adrift into contentedness.  Graziano and Conte, step aside, you've been dethroned by the new Best Sandwich in the World.  The Cubana is pure fried perfection, with ham, pork, pickles and mustard.  And the Pollo is right on its heels.  The fried plantains were also very good, but I wouldn't say they were as good as those found at Carnivale.  I'm craving all of this again right now.  I left my heart in 90 Miles.  As 90 Miles is a tiny place, you will want to be cognizant of when you go so that you don't end up in what I presume would be a long line at the lunch hour.  We were lucky enough to be victims of the time switch such that we were having a rather late lunch, so we encountered no lines.  But a line did form as we were enjoying our Cuban fare.   If 90 Miles is what's typical of Cuban fare, then it is time for Fidel and his brother to scram, for the embargo to end and for what I imagine is a beautiful country to open up to trade again.  But until then, it's my new love 90 Miles again for sure.  Cubanas for all! Six stars.

You gotta be kidding? How could something this good be so far away? And why in the h can't it be replicated in Indy? Where are all the Indy Cuban entrepreneurs?  I don't even remember what I ate cause I had retrograde amnesia from the orgasmic wave that hit be after the first bite.  Worth a three and a half hour road trip or a permanent move to Chi town. BTW only came here after reading Yelp reviews on nearby joints while freezing our ganorts off waiting in a ridiculously long line at Hot Doug's... glad we bailed!

We went here to celebrate our friend's bday.  The food was so delicious.  Everything including the apps tasted so fresh.  I have to say this location was the perfect spot for an intimate dinner with friends.  We had nine in our party and the dinner just flowed so well.  We staged our meal with many appetizers followed by our entrees.  The bday girl took charge in ordering the apps so I have no idea what was ordered.....only that we had a few different ones and everything was wonderful. This place is BYO....such a fun way to keep your meal cost down.  Only thing is that BYO can be dangerous when with a big group.....the drinks just keep flowing.

I was in the mood for some Cuban Coffee and got oh so much more :)  these guys rock the Cuban Sammich and Coffee, we were in the city and I was like hey lets find some Cuban Coffee, it is a shot of crack if made right and these guys make it right  but once we walked in the door and got a whiff of the food we had to eat also, The Ropa Vieja Sammich is the Bomb man I could eat these all week long, along with some yummy fried Plantains, man my mouth is watering think about that good meal we had, I see a trip into the city soon for some Cuban goodness   Good food Good Service oh yeah we will be back

Visited this place for the 3rd time today, except today I decided to bring my girlfriend who is a big is a big fan of cuban sandwhiches.  This place has yet to dissapoint, always delicious.  It is pretty small inside but if you can grab a counter space you are all set.  The walls are decorad with old newspaper clips and photos of Cuban history.  They also have a great patio space that looks like it would be great for the summer, espically becuase they are BYOB. I got the Lechon sandwhich is pulled pork, sweet plantians and grilled onions.  I also got an empanada.  My girlfriend got the cuban sandwhich and a side of paps fritas.  With soft drinks the total was about $19, so pretty well priced for all that you get. The food came out about 5 mintutes later.  Super fresh, hot and delicous.  The almost makes the sandwhich, it is super crunchy.  The meat is a good quality and there is lots of flavor.  Make sure to get some of the hot sauce they have sitting around the counter. It is really flavorful and makes a good punch. I give place 5 stars for great service, unique atomsphere and awesome cuban good. A place that is definetly a place in Chicago that is worth checking out.
Easy in and out.  Nice area to eat outside in the summer.  I have had a variety of their menu options and was always satisfied.  I enjoy their colorful and small restaurant.

Yes it's small, but good things come in small packages.  I believe 90 Miles makes the best Cuban Sandwhich in Chicago.  Writing about it, makes me crave one right now.    I have only been to the one on Clybourne, but I hear their Logan Square location is just as good.   Staff is friendly, and their is actually a small parking lot.

I have heard about this place from so many people and i FINALLY stopped in today! This is now in my TOP 5 places in Chicago! Their cute little place is so authentic, friendly, and their food is OUTSTANDING! Absolutely delicious! I can't say enough about this place and the price is great too!!

I was eating at 90 Miles for the first time on Tuesday as the blizzard was upon us.  I didn't want to leave in hopes that I would be trapped there forced to dine on empanadas until the storm passed. Definitely the best empanadas in the city - I tried the goat cheese, beef and chorizo.  All were equally delicious and perfect in everyway.  I topped those off with some sweet plantains and a couple bites of my friend's steak sandwich - the bread was perfection. I just moved to Roscoe Village and I now anticipate a major weight gain in my future.  Fml.

I had the most yummy lechon sandwich ever. I loved the greasiness of it, but sadly, because it's greasy, I won't be having another one until months later.  The sandwich was juicy. I was afraid that it was going to be dry. When I think of "roast pork," my experiences has mostly been with Chinese roast pork, which is usually more dry than it is juicy. The juiciness of the sandwich was the deciding factor for me when it came to deciding between the cubano and the lechon sandwich. My experience with a Cuban sandwich (the Milanesa) at Irazu was more dry than it was juicy, and I had a hard time finishing it. This was SO not the case with 90 Miles' lechon sandwich. The cashier recommended an iron beer for my drink. It's a Cuban soft drink that they import from Miami. It's not alcoholic, and it tasted faintly like root beer. It's funny that I actually considered and bought the drink because I was actually thinking of ginger beer when the guy mentioned it... I don't like root beer so it's usually not on my mind when I hear of a "beer" soft drink. And I'm glad the taste of iron beer isn't as strong as that of an American root beer.  The icon of a man flexing his bicep reminded me of Pop-Eye, which I thought was amusing. Of course, the man on the iron beer can was a lot younger and less White-looking. ;) My total for the whole meal was a little less than $10! Cheap AND delicious! It's a win! I also tried a sip of my friend's mamey shake. It was very rich and creamy, and very delicious! I have no idea what a mamey is, but it's some sort of fruit. I can't even describe what it tasted like... My friend said it tasted like maraschino cherries; I don't know if I agree with her, but apparently Wikipedia does! I think the next time I come here, I'll try the Cubano sandwich.
Yup, its true. They sure make a freakin good sandwich at this tiny hut.

I had breakfast here on a Saturday morning.  The staff was incredibly friendly, the place has a lot of character, the service is quick, the food has distinctive flavor and you won't walk away feeling as if you need to go back home and take a nap.   I chose an omelette sandwich with ham, swiss, onions, and fried sweet plaintains on a baguette roll.  I added a cafe cortadito and a pastry on the side, which came out to about $10 total.  It was a great deal.  They have a wide range of lunch sandwiches that I'll come back for sometime soon. The inside is decorated with old newspapers as wallpaper, as well as several photos and postcards of Cuba. They also provide a few decks of cards as a distraction for the 5 or so minutes till your food comes out. It's a comfortable and unique place.

Once upon a time, I became completely obsessed with the show "Dexter". I then became obsessed with all the delicious Cuban food Dexter & Co eat on the show. Then I couldn't stop thinking about Cuban sandwiches. What's a girl to do? Thank God I only live minutes away from 90 Miles.  I scarfed down the "Media Noche" sandwich, which is a Cuban sandwich (roast pork, ham, mustard, pickles, Swiss cheese) on sweet bread. Holy. Moly. That sandwich was a cornucopia of taste and textures. Crispy bread. Melty cheese. Crunchy pickles. Sigh.   I was slightly disheartened when mid-sandwich I saw a decorative sticker on the wall, of course it had a picture of a pig and a diagram of possibly a tapeworm (EEK) If you get scared off, I highly recommend you try the guava empanadas and fried plantains.

Sometimes, when I'm sad, probably because of the poor health decisions I made the night before, I get on my bike and cruise over to 90 Miles for a Lechon sandwich.  I think it's probably my favorite sandwich in the world, and after I eat it, I don't worry about feeling terrible anymore.  The pork is so tender and delicious, and the bread is crispy.  The hot sauce is killer in flavor and spice, which is difficult to accomplish.   I've never had anything other than the Lechon, because the thought of something else not being THE BEST sandwich I've ever had makes me hedge my bets and go for the old reliable.  However, I've heard that their other items are incredible as well. Also, try a mango tea drink thing if you want to drop the dough.  They're delicious and refreshing.

This has to be one of my favorite places in all of Chicago.  OK, my bias is heavily skewed because I live so close, but I have to find something on the menu I don't enjoy. Every sandwich is a perfect example of Cuban fare, the dinners are always so flavorful and generously portioned, and the cafe con leche is the perfect start to your day! This location is the small take-out heavy store. You can eat here though, as they have a u-shaped counter (you sit on the inside of the U) off to the left of the cash register area. Great for lunch!  The service here is always excellent too, and the bread pudding is not to be missed.

This place looks like a small little hut located in an area you wouldn't think to find good food at but it always seem to catch my attention every time I drive by.  I was lucky enough to be able to persuade my friend to come with me so we can have a little taste of Cuba, and I must say I was not disappointed!!! We ordered a cubano sandwich served w/a side of fried plantain chips, croquettas, a beef empanada and a cafe con leche.  The sandwich was delicious (especially the buttery/crispy bread they used) and for anyone who likes a little kick, just add some hot sauce and you'll be in sandwich heaven.  The plaintain chips were deliciously addicting and the croquettas were crispy on the outside and creamy on the inside.  The cafe con leche I must say brought my meal together and was a good end to my meal. The service was good and the prices were even better, I'd definitely come back here for a quick delicious meal.

The staff is unbelievably friendly and the atmosphere is fun. There is a covered, heated outdoor patio with great music.I had the ropa vieja which was delicious and the portion was huge! I had leftovers for the next day. Will definitely be going back.

***WARNING WARNING WARNING*** If you plan on ordering the ropa vieja do not wear anything nice because you will probably get the grease all over you. Now with that psa out of the way lets get down to biz here. I will admit I am not familiar with Cuban food and what is good and what isn't good. But I will say the food here is fair. I ordered up the ropa vieja, sword fish soup, cafe Cubana and goat cheese empanada. Like I said the ropa vieja is a messy sammie but it was good and had red sweet pepper which totally made the sammie and I hate sweet peppers cooked but it worked with the sammie. The bread was soft but had just enough firmness to not fall apart from the wetness of the sammie. The goat cheese empanada was pretty good can't complain. Sadly though I don't know what the sword fish soup tastes like. There was a glitch in the new pos and the kitchen never got the soup order and the folk behind the counter didn't catch it. The cafe Cubana I thought was delish! It was sweet but almost had a subtle liquor taste to it. I do think that I will be back as there were other things on the menu that were calling out my name.

I can't believe I neglected to review one of my favorite little joints! This place is AWESOME-O! The last "O" stands for "Oh, so!"  Cuisine: One of the best food stands around town with a big menu and decent portions n' prices. Now, I've never had home made Cuban, but if I did I expect it wouldn't be too different from 90M. Service: Happy/Attentive/Accurate. Diggs: TARDIS anyone? This place is super cool for being bigger on the inside than on the out. The Cubano newspaper clippins that plaster the walls can provide some good conversation or distract you till foods up.
I have tried this place twice and did not like it either time.  The sandwich was dry and the meat tough. I walked out feeling like I had garlic in my mouth for the next 12 hours.

It's places like 90 Miles that are causing me to move back to the NW side after a 3 year stint on the lake. Excellent fried plantain and empanada appetizers, la-la-la-lovely ropa vieja (enough for two meals!), and the best cafe con leche I've had in a loooong time. The price was right, the service was friendly, and their patio made us feel like we were outside - but it was so warm we could be in complete denial that 20 degrees awaited us upon departure. I cannot wait to go back soon!

I had gone in sometime ago with the expectation of the food being delicious. Disappointed I was:( The sandwich I had was a Cuban sandwich, (cheese and ham). It was barely any food on it and the price tag was too expensive for it. However the bread was fresh.  The customer service needed work. I haven't been back and sad for the business to say I won't be.

Today, my boyfriend wanted to have Cuban food and I said sure why not. So, were driving down Milwaukee and we came across 90miles. We walk in and were standing by the counter for roughly 5mins and if it wasn't for me asking the counter girl who do we talk to, to have a seat to I don't think anyone would've acknowledged us. She comes around the counter and asks how many? I told her 2, I ask her roughly how long the wait was. She says 30mins, it was 8:30 when she said 30mins. It was me and 2 other 2 people parties. 30mins later we see a lot of people leaving along with a few parties that left in the front end of the restaurant. No one came to seat along with people who came in after us who were 2 people parties were seated before us. My boyfriend goes up to one of the waiters and explains to him look we've been waiting for 40mins already people who came in after us were seated before us. The waiter then became ignorant and irritated because my boyfriend confronted him on the issue. He called another waiter to seat us when we get to the back room there were a lot of tables that were open. We get to our table and a busboy brought us water and we ended up sitting there for 30mins and again people who came in after us were already getting their order taken. When we have been sitting at that table for 30mins and not even a server came and asked us if we wanted to order anything to drink. This place is HORRIBLE ON SERVICE. No one ever came to our table to take any kind of order. So, we weren't even able to order any of this SO-CALLED good food. We just got up and walked the hell on out of there. They need to fix their service and not judge people.

great cubano sandwich.  I had the media noche (sweet bread), fried yucca w/ garlic topping.  For dessert I had bread pudding and a cafe con leche.  it was all terrific!  homemade and delicious.  would recommend.  only drawback was that it was small inside but cozy.  felt like i was in cuba for 30min.  parking too!

We live right down the street from this place, and it's a great spot for carry out.  The food is always cheap, tasty, and very affordable. While there are a lot of people that eat there, I wouldn't recommend it in the winter.  It's just a little teeny hut, and there's not a ton of room.

I wanted Burger King. Good thing my girlfriend put her foot down on that one. I went in pouting and came out a happy, pregnant looking skinny guy. The steak sandwich just exploded with flavor and the empanadas were out of this world!!  The guy at the front counter could tell we were new by the puzzled looks our pale white asses were giving the menu hanging and handed us the English version. He even made it a point to come out and see how the food was!  Looks like the king has be dethroned!

How did I miss out on this place? They have so many attractive items on the menu that it was hard to choose. The sandwiches are really good and the greenish sauce is a great touch to most of their sandwiches. I was glad that they had Malta to drink. The prices are cheap but I just wish it was located a little closer. Still gets 5 stars

Great food, decent prices, good service. This BYOB serves up some good Cuban eats.  Portions are large so that is good. My only complaint is that they need more sauces to be served.  The fried plantains had a garlic sauce served on it, but it really was just grated garlic... no sauce.
Omg...what a great place.  Staff is fantastic and the food is absolutely amazing.  Sitting here now sharing picadillo, croquetas and a media noche sandwich.  U must try it.

very small, but the sandwiches are above average.  i recommend the steak sandwich, the bread is good and thin so you can enjoy the ingredients more.  i think the real surprise are the espresso drinks, i don't know why but they are well above average.  wife gets the fish soup each time and raves about it.
this place is great. amazing atmosphere and the owner genuinely enjoys having you there. Its refreshing.  it can get crowded on the weekends but thats because its popular.
Excellent mix of cuisine. Relaxing place. Especially in summer.

I don't have much Cuban food experience but several people have attested that it is authentic.   Tips: - Not much indoor seating space.  Just a counter really.  No place to lounge around. - Cuban espresso doesn't mess around.  It is really strong. - All the different types of Yuca are fantastic. - Their house hot sauce is a personal favorite.

hm. seemed like a ton of hype from yelp. guess i missed the train. I ordered the lechon sandwhich and was pretty disappointed. A brick of pork between two chunks of bread.  the meat was tender and well cooked, but lacking in flavor. great if you love to challenge your arteries.  it came with  onions (which didn't enhance much of anything)  and sweet plantain-- if only there were more of it into the sandwich. I just was completely disinterested in eating it. half of my meat was removed as i ate it. my bf tried the ropa viejo? ( might have botched the name). It was with a shredded beef, smothered in sauce, but with some peppers I think. It just reminded me of a beefy stew in a sandwich.  little soggy. little salty. the house hot sauce didn't really do much to change flavors for me either. i dunno. i really appreciate the spot for what it is. better quality than a grab-n-go for sure. it's a pleasant break away from typical grease joints. but still. no ball out of the park for me. if you're on the run and dont want a huge sit-down experience, i would keep this place in mind. otherwise, i'm a bit indifferent.  the waitress was very helpful in suggesting items to me, since i was clueless. but i still don't think that the place warrants a "tip slot" on the bill, since it's not as though they truly wait on you other than hand you your plate.  (it's the kinda place where you eat your grub and toss out your tray like in a cafeteria). but is it cheap? yes. decent? yes. but next time maybe i'll just sample the sides like the empanada, tamal, n flan.

I'm a Puerto Rican from New York. Born in Puerto Rico. Aside from Puerto Rican food which is similar,  I've had good and bad Cuban food and I most say that 90 Miles Cuban Cafe has some of the best Cuban food I've ever had. I had a Cuban sandwich with fried Yuca. My girlfriend also had the Cuban with tostones. I don't add many bookmarks but this one is a must for future visits to Chicago!!! If your expecting a full blown restaurant with a waiter/waitress this isn't it. But if your are looking for outstanding Cuban food and can get over what you may normally expect, then this is it! Unlike other reviews, my service was good. As I sat outside and enjoyed the weather and my food, the locals were non-stop stopping for carry out. A clear indication on how good the food is. The other important fact to point out is that if your a person that normally seasons food with just salt and pepper, your taste buds may not know how to act when you taste well seasoned Cuban food. So if your taste buds don't agree, it's not the food. So don't be fast to blame the food and accept that maybe you just haven't had authentic Cuban food!!! One more thing, don't judge this neighborhood treasure by the size of the building. Great things come in small packages!!!!

I'm writing a much overdue follow up.  After writing my initial review, the manager immediately contacted me, asked for my name and found it on their list of credits.  She apologized and promptly sent a gift certificate.  We haven't been back yet, I of course lost the certificate, but will definitely give them another try in the future. My big gripe on my initial review was the lack of customer service, they definitely turned that around.  Mistakes happen and I forgive.  Looking forward to giving them another shot!

Truthfully, I'm not someone who gets all excited about sandwiches. So when my best buddy raved about this place, I was like 'Eh, ok, let's go."   My reaction? Mmmm, (smack lips), Mmmm mm mmm. This place ROCKS! Bless the creators of this tasty sandwich.  I ordered the Bistec sandwich off of the lunch menu, but for dinner.  (yep you can order dinner off of the lunch menu). Super cheap - under 6 bucks.  This is one of those sandwiches that makes you crave for more. The steak cuts were juicy, warm and tender. Topped with refreshing romaine lettuce, tomato, grilled onions,and  shoestring potatoes. Everything is fresh! Atmosphere-wise, don't expect much - it's definitely just a small tiny cafe, might be better for takeout & super casual. I'd heard the Armitage location might have bigger seating but i think this Clybourn location is the original one. So if it's good cuban yummies  you're looking for, you've come to the right place!!

The Guajarito is one of the best sandwiches on the planet.  The cafecito is phenomenal.  Both locations are BYOB.  The Clybourn location is good for carryout.  For sit down, the one on Armitage has a much better atmosphere.

Great Steak sandwich! and i love the plantains I went there this past weekend it was the second time for me and it was just as good the second time as it was the first! One of my North side favorites.

I wasn't impressed with this location at all.  My friend had the bistec dinner and she barely ate any of it.  I took a piece, didn't care for it so she ended up throwing it out.   The only empanada I thought tasted decent was the ropa vieja, but the sauce they give to accompany them was way too oily and therefore had no flavor.  I brought a chorizo and goat cheese home for my mom and I don't care for goat cheese, so I didn't like that one but the chorizo was way too salty.  I tried a beef at the restaurant and didn't care for it.  I should have just ordered 3 ropa viejas and called it a day. The white rice was good.  I normally don't eat white rice, but when it comes to latin food, it usually tastes different so I try it.  The fried yuca had way too much garlic on it, and this is coming from someone who enjoys garlic.   I won't be coming back here unless someone makes me.  I can get rice at many other places and there are many other places I get can empanadas.  Maybe I should have tried a dinner different than my friend's, but nothing on the menu jumped out.

So one Saturday, late morning, the gentleman friend and I decide that our hangovers need some food. He suggests this place because it's really close, so they'll deliver quickly. My hangover cure is a good sandwich and a coke, so I order the veggie sandwich and a coke. OVER 2 PAINFUL HUNGOVER HOURS LATER....our food comes, but the delivery guy forgets the coke. We steal his pen and tell him he'll get the pen and his tip, when he comes back with the soda. He did, so he got his pen and his tip. (point being he clearly didn't have to come back...we took his pen for God's sake...but he did. props to him for that) Now onto the food...absolutely delicious, holy potatoes was that an amazing sandwich. And the restaurant threw in some extra goodies because we had to call 3 -4 times to get the food... So they lost 2 points because I A) had to wait over 2 hours to get fed, and 2 hours is a LONG time, regardless of me being hungover or not. B) Because I was STARVING when the food finally came, I may have eaten anything and thought it was delicious. I drive past there a lot, and the place looks fun - I'm looking forward to giving them another shot.

The food is amazingly good.  I have been impressed each time that I have gone, however all three times I went, they were out of the daily special :(  I guess that is a good thing, meaning it must sell out quickly.   The desserts are sweet and tasty and the portions are large enough to fill you up!

Im a huge fan of Cuban sandwiches/dishes and decided to have 90 Miles Cuban Cafe delivered at work.  I ordered the Ropa Vieja (shredded beef in cajun sauce) dinner with Congri Rice (black beans rice). It normally comes with white rice and black beans but I had it substituted.  The meal also comes with maduros (sweet plantains).  My dish had just the right seasonings.  I've been restricting my salt intake lately and I was afraid it may be too salty but it was just right.  I would have to say it was on the oily/greasy side.  The dinner plates are $9.95 which isn't horrible, but not a bargain either.   Portions are decent and the food flavorful! I could really use a nap right about now.  This comfort food just hits the spot and cravings fulfilled. Last but not least, please try the Salida del Sol iced tea.  Not only is it delicious, it's beautiful to look at!  It looks like a sunset in a cup.  Im definitely returning for more!

Been here 3 times and i was dying to give them 5 stars but our last visit was not as great as the first two. I understand people and restaurants have off nights. I work in the industry and am very forgiving in these matters, but I have noticed some trends at 90 miles. My gf always, ALWAYS asks for extra hot sauce or chimichuri  or whatever spicy sauce is to be had at wherever we are eating. Every time we have been to 90 miles she has asked for extra hot sauce and never has it been brought to us upon our first request. No big deal, she's needy sometimes and I love her for it. The last visit our server was friendly and knowledgeable. Two traits that go a long way with me as a diner. But, he was overextended in his section and told us so. Perhaps a server called in, someone got fired, who knows? So, we didnt have silverware when our appetizers came, had to wait several minutes before someone on the staff could help us. Our server gave us our pitcher of Mojito mix without a spoon. How the hell do we dig out the ice cubes? A fork? Our grubby alcoholic fingers?? The hot sauce thing again. Asked for extra limes, took forever to get them. Basically we got poor service from a cool dude in a place we love to go to. I dont know if the service concerns at 90 miles are indicative of deeper issues at the restaurant, but I hope they get resolved. When this place is ON, it is one of my favorite all time Chicago spots.

Amazing sandwiches...just really, really well done.  I've had the Cubano (traditional Cuban) and the Lechon (pork, garlic sauce and grilled plantains) so far, and both were outstanding.  Really good fries, too...unique crunch and flavor to them. The atmosphere is friendly and laid back, with very chilled decor and a nice outdoor patio.  Nice assortment of coffee drinks, pastries and yerba mate sodas to round out the experience. Oh, and tasty shakes.  Totally worth the hype.

After living a stone's throw away from 90 Miles for a couple years, I can finally say I've tried it. Damn is it good! What took me so long???  I stopped in to grab some dinner to take home after a very long day at the office. I honestly wanted to try everything on their menu, but settled for the bistec dinner and an order of croquetas. The bistec was tender and juicy and covered with onions, garlic, and other wonderful things of which I do not know the name. The rice was yummy and went perfectly with everything else. The plantains were very sweet, a nice change up from the bistec. The croquetas were awesome, as fried, diced ham sticks should be!  Huge portions? Yuh huh. I was famished and there was enough food to fill me up and still have a complete dinner for the next night. The people there are very cool, I ordered based solely off their recommendations and was very pleased. The food was up very quickly, but not at the expense of being cooked before I ordered it.  I'll be back early and often, perhaps for breakfast next time!
awesome food!  sandwiches are to die for!  their chicken dinner is perfect and the portion is huge (you can share it with your best half if you want to)!

A lovely little shack of a place that serves delicious Cuban-style food. Nice outdoor seating area, not much at all in terms of indoors. Descriptions of the food could have been better; I got the tofu dinner. All I knew was that it came with tofu, white rice, black beans and plantains. Thankfully they did something with the tofu, cooking it in some kind of tasty sauce that contained large chunks of peppers and onion.  Properly prepared Cuban-style black beans and rice are a combo everyone must try at least once, and this is a good place to do it. This place won't impress your date until she tastes the food. I am a fan, and I like to pleasantly surprise people.
Yummy Cuban sandwiches, pretty good papas fritas, and good drink options (passion fruit iced tea or maracuya shake). Outdoor seating as well. : ) I definitely plan to come back here.

So after a great night of partying and waking up super hungry it didn't matter what I wanted to eat, I just knew I needed FOOD!!!! So after much thought into finding a place close by our place, my boyfriends suggested to go to 90 Miles Cuban Café. So we got out of bed, showered, got dressed and heading our way out the door. We walking to this place from Montrose to Clybourn which is about 3 miles, at this time we were extremely hungry and antsy to get there. So after a 30 minute walk we finally got there. It smelled delicious!!! We were so excited to walk in order and stuff ourselves.  I order the, "Bistec dinner", which includes a medium size pork steak, caramelized onions, garlic, cilantro, black beans, white rice and fried plantains all for $9.95 plus tax. My boyfriend order , "Ropa Veija", which is shredded pork cooked in their Cuban sauce ( the portion of this dish is very generous), black beans, white rice and fried plantains for $9.95 plus tax. We didn't order drinks, we had complimentary water they had by their counter but the food was awesome for my tummy!!!  Overall, 90 Miles Cuban Café is a great Cuban restaurant. Their decor is very vintage, which I love. They have old Cuban newspaper articles, magazine ads, Cuban fashion, Cuban posters and old family photos in Cuba all posted around the walls. They don't have many seats inside, but they do have an open patio which you can sit and its BYOB! I recommend this great little spot between Clybourn and Belmont. Whether your hungry, not so hungry or in the mood for Cuban food. You should definitely go there.
Love Love Love this place! I could eat there everyday but my jeans wouldn't allow it. The food is so DElicious :) Can't wait to try their restaurant.

90 Miles you truly are the forbidden food. You are too close to my office. If I ate here as much as I really want to your tender meats stuffed between buns with that delicious drippy garlicy sauce, fried plantains and papas fritas would blow me up like a balloon.  My mouth is watering now as I write this so I'm going to have to end it here and try to stop thinking about those sandwiches.

Since I moved to Chicago from South Florida I have really missed casual Cuban fare, however, this is no longer the case. After going to 90 miles my urge for Cuban cuisine can be satisfied. My husband had the Bistec dinner when we went and I had the Ropa Vieja dinner, both were incredible. The proteins were delicious, as were the rice and beans and plaintains. I am totally in love with this food. I can't wait to go back.  So freaking good...

I was in town last weekend and needed to find a place to eat in their area. After seeing positive review after positive review, I decided to force my friend to go here. She trusts me and I trust Yelp so...it works. I think the look and feel of the place is great. It's small. Limited inside seating. The outdoor patio area had more seating and given the weather and the awkwardness that is sitting/eating/having to constantly look left or right to talk to your company it was a must do.  I've only had Cuban a couple times in the Detroit area so by no means do I consider myself an aficionado. I will say, however, that I've heard hundreds of people talk about how the Cuban sandwich is a Godsend and yet I have not had one good experience ordering it. I ordered one at 90 Miles hoping for redemption and much to my surprise...it delivered. Great sandwich.  The side (fried plantains) were nice because they are an interesting upgrade to fries (or any variation of fries) but the 3-5 small pieces seemed inadequate in comparison to the sandwich price. I also thought the sandwich creation process seemed pretty slow as a hole but everyone was nice so it wasn't a major dilemma.

I stumbled upon this place for lunch one afternoon when taking my dog to the vet and I must say, I was impressed. The ambiance is very casual with a festive decor and the option to eat indoors or out. When I informed the waitress taking my order it was my first time there, she eagerly inquired if the order was for me and provided her recommendation of the cuban garden salad with avocado. The service was great and the dog friendly patio lunch was just what I needed at the time. The chicken garden salad came with tomatoes/onions, added avocado, was very well seasoned and left no disappointment.....very tasty. I must say, I will definitely be back!
Perfect weather and timing to slip in some dinner on the patio on a busy evening.  First time trying ropa vieja sandwich.  Good pick!

First and foremost: Don't sleep on their espresso. I believe it's toward the end of the menu, and they do many good things with it . . . sweetened shots or a cafe con leche. I have been here a couple times and have tried their bigger entrees (more expensive) and have also tried their sandwiches too. I absolutely love their food, and I really dig their concept. Totally worth it. But I should mention their site has different prices posted. Note: Although I am a stickler for such details, this place is not loosing stripes, I mean stars.

I think that even if this place was 90 miles away, I'd still try to get there as often as possible.  For a place that borders on "fast food" this place just rocks.  Just rocks.  Now, stop reading and go get some plantains!
Good food at a very affordable price, love that it is walking distance from my home. Very limited seating indoors but they have a patio outside.

My first time experiencing Cuban food and it was an overall good experience. I'd return to eat there. I went for dinner. Very different atmosphere according to my friend who went for lunch. There were a few birthday parties and it was constantly loud and festive. Not a bad thing, but not for those who like to dine in silence. Also, prices for the same items are higher at dinner than at lunch.  Interior is festive; gives the restaurant a lot of character. They use jars as water cups! Love it. I tried their sweet plaintains (maduros) as an appetizer -- but it was a hefty portion that my two friends and I could not finish. Got the bistec sandwich -- very tasty. Full of meat and ingredients. Meat was very thick and juicy -- a little too greasy. My bread started to fall apart on account of the grease. Also offers shakes.

Had big expectations from this place  a) Had some nostalgic memories and Cuban cuisine of my trip to Miami b) Hungry Hound had wonderful reviews of this place, as it was featured on last week on Channel 7 Food + Vacation= Heaven Had the skirt steak dinner, with white rice, black beans and plantains.  I was VERY disappointed in the skirt steak. I thought the outside would have a sort of char, still keeping the inside the medium rare that I always order for my steaks.  Not the case...I dunno if it was steam mixed with the take out box it came in, but it made the steak very chewy, almost as if the meat was BOILED.  Gross The accompanying sides were the savior, and again, because of the fact that it was take out, I'd be willing to give 90 miles another try and a fair shot dining in.

So taking the 'rents for breakfast and we chose 90 Miles.  Lesson learned.  This is not really the place to go for breakfast-y options.  Although omelets are present on the menu, they weren't really "Cuban" style.  So in an effort to put some Cuban into my egg white omelet, I added salsa, ordered up empanadas de ropa vieja, shared in some maduros, and sipped a café latte.  Will be sure to go back here and give it a try for lunch or dinner options, but pass on the "breaking-fast" and drive right by to one of the many other Chicago brunch options.
Outstanding spot for lunch.  A bit slow, but worth it if you're not in a hurry.

Great cuban cafe.  I've been here only once and had a cubano and some yuca con mojo.  I used to live in south florida so I'm always excited to find a good restaurant in the midwest to get my cuban fix.  I tried my friend's tofu sandwich, which had a creole black bean sauce on it and was likewise very tasty.  They have a lot of other interesting options on the menu; i look forward to going back and trying some of their other vegetarian options as well as their sweet plantains.   The place is tiny and feels like a proper hole-in-the-wall.  Which is exactly where I expect to find great food for a great price!

So this place was great. The food was amazing.  The ropa Vieja sandwich was delicious.  And they were dog friendly, with the water and biscuit for my min pin.  So good that I couldn't get enough, I had to come back the next day. 2 days in a row you say? That's insane?! Is it? You might just do the same as I did. Plus it didn't hurt that the girl taking my order was hot. I never got a chance to ask her out tho because she left the state for school.

Love, love, love.  Pros: The chimichurri beef was absurdly good (though slightly on the salty side, but I like salt). Goat cheese empanadas - wowsers. BYOB and I did. Good service. Cons: My husband's ropa vieja sandwich was a little dry (or something was off) for me, but he loved it.  GO GO GO. Right now. :)

I must say that since coming to 90 miles, there really is no more room for another Cuban place. It has been said that once you try Cuban sandwiches you will never experience another sandwich quite the same.  I think the melding of flavors is just the right pitch. From the garlic infused meats to the platanos maduros. Wow, just like old time sakes, a bit of the paste with a twist. You will not be sorry you came here.

A little surprised at the location of this place, we were taken aback by the full menu. Guessing our surprise, we were immediatly assisted with choosing the perfect lunch...and it was. Yum. Tiny little place that looks like it should have a drive up window, too cozy inside for my taste, but a cute outdoor area makes it tolerable. Too bad I can't enjoy my cuban in the winter time.

So last night I was watching food network and on Throwdown, they had a Cuban Sandwich challenge.  I asked around where to get a good Cubano Sandwich and everyone answered "90 miles".  I then searched "Cuban Sandwich" on Yelp and "90 miles" came up the #2 answer (#1 is closed though).  A coworker also mentioned they had good Tostones (fried green plantains). Suprisingly, I've been to "90 miiles" a number of times but never tried (or even noticed on the menu) the Cubano.  I like the Chicken dinner plate with a huge butterflied grilled chicken breast smothered in onions with rice, beans, and sweet plantains. Anyhow, this time, I switched it up.  I got the Cubano I was craving from watching Throwdown and I got the recommended Tostones.  The Cubano was a very good ham and cheese - basically a Croque-Monsieur with a Cuban twist.  The bread was toasted and pressed perfectly to crunch on the outside and be a bit chewy on the inside.  The combination of fresh sliced pork with ham, cheese, pickle, and mayonnaise was quite traditional and definitely hit the spot. I was a bit disappointed by the Tostones -- I think Irazu's are better.  I didn't finish my order of Tostones and neither did my other coworker who ordered them -- so I'll definitely skip those next time.  I wish I would have gotten one of their awesome shakes instead. The Clybourne location for this restaurant is a very small place with no tables inside (counters) and is not good for big groups.  Best to do takeout or just close friends.

We were seated right away in the outdoor area and really liked the ambiance.  I would have to say waiting 20 minutes for a server to take our order made me want to get up and leave.  Every table around us was taken and had a very attentive server but wasn't sure why each server saw us, but kept on walking.  Finally, Henry the manager took care of us, but it shouldn't have gone to that extent.

I ate here once a while ago and although I don't remember what I ordered, I do remember that it was delicious and definitely worth the money. I love the fact that they're BYOB and the staff was super friendly! Definitely recommend going there for a casual meal!

My take out order was messed up so that was not a good start.  I had to make my own rice since they forgot to put it in.   I might as well have cooked the whole meal.  The ropa vieja and frijoles negros were kind of tasteless.  Too many Latin places I've been to in Chicago leave out the authentic ingredients and spices and everything comes out tasting just plain salty and one dimensional.  This is one of them.  I don't get all the hyped up reviews - either they come from people too far removed from the real thing and what it's supposed to taste like or they're friends of the house. Sorry, but not worth it.

I was at this location a week to a week and a half ago. I was utterly disappointed. I thought the Armitage location was bad. Well, at least the food (for the most part) there is good but service is bad (though my recent staff experience there greatly improved).  I ordered the fish special. The fish was not supposed to be fried but it, along with the rice and veggies came standing (literally) in a pool of olive oil. The fish was also very dry, even tough in places.

My husband And I have been meaning to try this place for a long time, and we were not disappointed. We both had the chicken dinner, and it was excellent. Fantastic grilled onions and beans and rice, and plantains. Yum! We also tried the beef empanadas, and the ham croquettes, and they were both good too, but not that different than what I've had elsewhere.  I've heard the sandwiches are amazing, I look forward to going back. I wish there was a little more comfortable seating, but only because it was too hot for their patio.

(Back in January, I set out on a road trip from the Twin Cities to Toledo, Ohio. I decided to make it a culinary trip, visiting six restaurants between St. Paul and Chicago. I tweeted reviews at the time in 140 characters or less, but here is a more extensive review) "Small eating area. Impressive plantain sandwich. Soild empanadas. Strong cafe cubano. Friendly service. 4.5/5" After being stuffed four times today, I picked up my friend at O'Hare and we went to search for dinner. Well HE searched. We initially stopped by Kuma's, hoping the crummy weather would keep people away. No sir, the wait was 3.5 hours even with the rain coming down outside. Wow. That's okay, I had another place in mind. Today was a day of culinary firsts for me (historic boxcar diner, Norwegian lefse, German weiner schnitzel, limburger cheese) so I was hoping to try my first cuban food. And I had heard about 90 mile, and it was nearby. Was it fate? We almost missed it when we drove by the first time. Wait, this little corner building was the epicenter of cuban food in Chicago? Something must be wrong here ... We walk in, and there was a couple people ahead of us. There was just six or so stools lined up around the back of the building. Very small indeed. The menu had a decent selection of authentic cuban food. I settle on a sandwich I had heard about where the white bread was replaced with plantains. Oh my goodness, what a great combination. My friend got empanadas which we shared. Solid tasting. I also had the cafe cubano which was nicely strong, enjoyable. While we were waiting for our food and eating, we saw activity pick up. This location was busy for deliveries and pickups, we were the only ones to sit and eat. At one point there were over twenty people waiting for food inside. I don't know how they do it and not get overwhelmed! But I can see why the place is popular, even though it don't look like much from the ouside. Amazing food. Amazing find. Totally unexpected.
LOVE this place! It is very authentic to the little cuban eateries in Miami. I ony wish they had an avocado salad! Love the black beans and rice, great tostones, cuban bread authentic.....so good!

This place may be on an odd corner and not look like much from afar, but it's packed with flavor. It's easy to drive by and not know what 90 Miles is all about. I've been doing it for the longest time. One day I had a craving for a good Cuban sandwich on the north side and made my way here. They have a small lot that will fit maybe 7 cars and it's never a problem to get in there for a weekday lunch. They have a nice variety of sandwiches to choose from and even some vegetarian selections if that's your thing. They also have a great variety of sides, various preparations of plantains and cassava. I've had a Cubano, Media Noche, and Bistec sandwich so far. All of them come with a few fried plantain chips which are light and crunchy. The sandwiches all brim with flavor; the meat is juicy and well spiced. The breads toasted texture compliments the meat well and really soaks up the juices without falling apart. I did order the steak with fried plantains as the bun instead of bread once too, though I can't remember what the name for it was. Even though it's a little starchy and leaks oil like a BP spill I can't help but love the concept and execution. There are a few imported soft drinks as well which are a little on the sweet side (cane sugar) but great to try and pair well with the saltiness of the food. The employees are awesome and the girls behind the counter are engaging. They bring your food out to you and with the outdoor seating area you get a mini-vacation vibe. Prices are reasonable and the portions are filling. While the cubano sandwich isn't my number one in the city (Cafecito gets that nod) it's still a great spot. Get down there now and check out this place before the lines form.

I LOVE IT! There is tom of out door seating.Another Great BYOB spot for some lunch on a nice day, or a great priced summer dinner. I had the Sopa de pollo, it was good home style with torn chicken off the bone, big potatoes, and spaghetti noodles. (YUM! I'm a sucka for good soup!) Yuca con Mojo which wasn't dry! My only criticism was the Tostones where on the thick patty size (NOT my thang when it comes to tostosnes I prefer thinner and more well done) OH Yea great Cuban Sandwich ham and moist Pork! Yummy!! Authentic for sure... I dont mind paying about a dollar more than the shack down the street the set up is nice for crowds and NO Cork fee for BYOB. I believe consistency is worth that extra cent. I'll be back soon.

My husband was kind of skeptical when we drove up to this tiny shed-like restaurant with murals all over its walls, but I was convinced this was a gold mine based on all the yelp reviews. And the rumors were true! We went around 1:00 PM on a Friday. Parking was not incredibly difficult even though the 4-5 space parking lot was full. We parked on a side street. We walked in and yes, it's small but we were immediately greeted by a friendly staff. The place actually looks kind of homey with walls covered by Cuban newspapers and old photographs.  Initially we were stumped by the inadequately described menu that was on display (although I must say the chalkboard menu displays are super cute ) but they also had paper menus with more description, similar if not exactly the same as the menu on the website. I already knew what I wanted but my husband has some food allergies and he wanted to make sure he knows what to expect. The kind lady behind the counter was knowledgeable enough to help right away.  My husband got the bisteak (steak sandwich) and I got the pulled beef. We got them to go since there was no room to sit. Every single bar stool at the wrap-around bar, the only seating there is, was taken. There is a cute little patio with umbrellas but it was scorching  outside. I would have really liked to stay and enjoy the music as well as the ambiance. This is the reason I deducted one star. Even as we waited for our food for about 10-15 minutes, there was no room to sit.  After a forty minute drive home (due to traffic), the sandwiches got a little soggy, especially  my pulled beef since it was wetter than the steak sandwich. My pulled beef was soaked in a red sauce along with strips of onions and green pepper. It tasted phenomenal! The bread, you could tell, was fresh. My husband's steak sandwich came with romaine? lettuce and tomatoes(?). Sorry, by that point I was in a trance state from how good my sandwich tasted that I didn't really pay attention to what I was tasting of my husband's sandwich. I do remember the meat was top quality and moist. In addition, my husband, a hot-sauce aficionado, got their hot sauce on the side. The hot sauce was not the hottest thing I ever tried but it went well with the sandwiches. I give 5/5 for the taste. The portion size of each sandwich was adequate for me even though I was starving by that point. Great value for your money at $6.50 each for lunch. This one, I will recommend to all my friends and will visit again.

The place was so cute, the food was so-so. Biggest complaint at my table? All our  breads were dry, and not much on the sandwich to "juice" it up. Rather expensive for what you get ($11 something for a sandwich and a side). The service was good.

Went yesterday for lunch.... Once again, TOP NOTCH. Great service, great atmosphere and the food was amazing. Steak sandwich was the best steak sandwich I've ever had. Fries were amazing. The beef empanada was incredible. WOW! :)

With 200 + reviews, there's no reason for me to write about how great the food was here, how fresh and homemade it tasted, and how nice the staff was. So I won't. I will, however, register my approval with a five star rating and a "six flags, more flags, more fun" comment, just to get my review count up. So, Six Flags, more flags more fun!

I came back for more, because it was so good the first time - and this time it was even better! I got the Guajirito: green plantains (instead of bread), skirt steak, grilled onions, swiss cheese, and a slice of lettuce/tomato. YUMMMMMMM.  It was served hot, fresh out of the oven/grill/whatever they cooked it on.  It was a little greasy, but the cheese was gooey, the steak was juicy, the plantains were sweet, and I was in love.  Strawberry iced tea was delicious as well. I'm considering coming back here once a week until I try everything, since it just keeps getting better!

Went there on Saturday with friends...I love caribean food and it was not disapointing....for starters we had the "mariquitas", "yuca" and chifles...everything delicious...I had the fish and eventhough it was scary it was really good ..the best thing was the rice...loved the rice! .we are going back for sure!!! good prices and service! We even danced with the waiter...;)

Superb Cuban sandwiches.  The three of us had the lechon, cubano, and the media noche.  We also had the empanadas.  The overall impression was excellent quality food!  This is the place to go for some quality cuban sandwiches with some excellent flavor and taste!!!  We will definitely be coming back and bringing our Cuban family to enjoy!

A Cuban treasure! Fresh authentic cuban food, the best coffee in town. Try the Lechon dinner, melt in your mouth pork with rice and beans. Their home made hot sauce is just amazing and just the right amount of heat. I wish it was the space was bigger, don't expect to hang out for long, but maybe that is the point, get your amazing food and GO! Decor is very ingenious, probably what a restaurant in Cuba looks like today.

EMPANADAS! EMPANADAS! GET YOUR EMPANADAS HERE!  Yes, I am an empanada FREAK! I love them. Living in and visiting South America got me into this mess, and I have no desire to lose the taste! You often see empanadas on menus in Chicago- but I have not found a place yet that are as close to what I prefer (which is- of course- the right way to make them).  90 Miles does empanadas right!  They are crispy, pretty light, and VERY flavorful. Today, because I was in the area, I grabbed a beef and a goat cheese. While the goat cheese is not what I typically had in BA, it was wonderful, goat cheese and a red pepper flavor. The beef was savory and delicious! The pork and others are good too (just not as fresh in my memory.)  The Cafe con Leche here is also awesome! They do it iced in the summer, hot in the winter- anyway you want it- that's the way you need it.
